[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

such behavior may indicate a non-villager trying to blend in or avoid suspicion.] [4]\n[4] [Monitor the outcomes of votes and eliminations to assess a player\'s alignment; village members often suffer from misjudgments while werewolves may steer votes towards innocent players.] [3]\n[5] [Evaluate players\' roles based on their advocacy for certain players and resistance to revealing or believing credible information shared by confirmed village-aligned players.] [3]\n[6] [Pay attention to how players respond to accusations or suspicions raised against them; villagers tend to provide explanations or evidence for their innocence, while werewolves may divert attention or remain overly defensive.] [3]\n[7] [Consider if a player\'s advocacy against a werewolf is consistent over time or if it is primarily reactionary; werewolves may occasionally support a vote against another werewolf to appear trustworthy.] [3]\n[8] [Track reactions to accusations and the flow of the discussions post these accusations, as villagers typically seek to clarify while werewolves may manipulate or stay quiet.] [3]\n[9] [Observe the consistency of players\' voting patterns with their stated beliefs and the village consensus; My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. When multiple sources point to a consistent pattern, such as the seer\'s claims being substantiated by events or players\' consistent voting that aligns with those claims, confidence in these insights should increase. Conversely, inconsistent or erratic behavior should cast doubt on a player\'s alignment with village goals.] [10]\n[2] [Consider the overall contribution of a player to the village\'s discussions and decision-making process. Players who offer logical, constructive, and consistent input that aligns with the seer\'s visions and the village\'s interests may increase confidence in their villager status. True support will likely be accompanied by actionable suggestions and a pattern of voting with the seer\'s insights, whereas false support might lack substance or seem conveniently timed.] [8]\n[4] [Take into account any instance where a player\'s elimination logically supports the seer\'s previous accusations. If a player who was accused by the seer is then eliminated in subsequent rounds, this may retrospectively indicate the accuracy of the seer\'s vision. This should increase confidence in the seer\'s future visions as well as in identifying potential werewolves.] [4]\n[5] [If a player who was previously aligned with or defended by a confirmed werewolf begins to shift blame or distance themselves without a clear rationale after the werewolf\'s identity is revealed or suspected, consider this behavior as a significant factor to reassess the player\'s potential alignment.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. What could happen is: After I heal Player 1, I think these things would happen. If Player 1 is targeted by werewolves during the night, my action could save them, allowing us another day with all players alive. This would then create a sense of trust between Player 1 and myself, although my role would still be hidden. Player 1 could turn out to be a valuable asset to the village if they are on the villager team and could be a crucial part of our decision-making process moving forward.\n\nHowever, if Player 1 is not targeted by the werewolves, the night would pass without incident, and my role would remain a secret. This could be seen as an inefficient use of the medic\'s heal if it were to become known, but it would also mean that the werewolves targeted someone else, possibly revealing their strategy or patterns to the village.\n\nOn the other hand, if Player 1 is a werewolf or has a negative role and my heal saves them, this could complicate the villagers\' efforts to find and eliminate the werewolves. It would also mean one of the actual villagers is more vulnerable during the night.\n\nIf Player 1 is not killed and there are no deaths during the night, other players may suspect that they are a werewolf saved by a medic or that the werewolves chose not to kill anyone to create confusion. In such a case, it might direct unnecessary suspicion towards Player 1, which could lead to false accusations or a wrongful vote-out.\n\nIn any case, I must be careful not to reveal my role and remain observant of the reactions and information that emerge after the night phase, especially concerning Player 1\'s actions and contributions to discussions, as it could provide insights into their role and the general dynamics among players.\n\nCase B: Heal Player 5. What could happen is: After I heal Player 5, I think these things would happen. Since there is currently no basis to suspect any player more than another, and no one has died yet, healing Player 5 would be a preventative measure without specific evidence to justify it. If Player 5 is attacked during the night by a werewolf and my healing action saves them, it would reveal to me that Player 5 is likely a target for the werewolves and possibly a villager of significance, though it would not publicly reveal my role as the medic yet. This information could be useful in later rounds to better protect key village players.\n\nOn the other hand, if Player 5 is not attacked, no one will be aware of my action, and there will be no immediate impact from my decision. However, it would mean I\'ve potentially wasted my healing ability for that round, which might have been better utilized if I had more information or if there was a revealed seer or other important village role that needed protection.\n\nMy healing action could also have indirect consequences. If Player 5 behaves suspiciously in the subsequent day phase and the village votes to execute them, finding out that they are indeed a villager might cause others to wonder if a medic was protecting them, bringing unseen attention towards me and other players who defended Player 5. Additionally, other players\' behavior after the heal, like their voting patterns or accusations, might give me more insight into potential alliances or werewolf identities.\n\nOverall, I expect a subtle influence on the game\'s progress and for my role to remain hidden for the time being, while I continue to observe and analyze player behavior for future rounds.\n\nNow, please choose to Heal one of these 2 players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to Heal this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to Heal Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

According to rule [0], I should weigh the trust dynamics within the group and the timing of my revelation to ensure that my announcement leads to effective group action and not my own early dismissal. I\'d also need to follow rule [3], strategizing the most effective way to communicate my evidence, perhaps initially sharing it with trusted individuals as per rules [5] and [6].\n\n- If Player 1 is a villager, I could use this information to build trust with them subtly, as per rule [7], especially if they have a protective role. However, it\'s important that I keep the knowledge of their innocence to myself and perhaps one or two trusted individuals to avoid making them a target, unless it\'s strategically beneficial to reveal their role later.\n\n- Regardless of Player 1\'s role, I must be aware of the potential risks to myself should I reveal my seer identity. Rule [4] suggests using indirect tactics for protection, whereas rule [8] warns about the backlash of revealing information, urging me to be prepared with protective strategies.\n\n- In my interaction with the group, following rule [1] would be crucial, as acting as a lone wolf (no pun intended) might lead to ostracization or disbelief from the group, especially if a villager gets wrongly accused due to my actions.\n\n- I would use this event and any future visions to help inform my understanding of the group\'s dynamics, as suggested by rule [9], to differentiate between the tactics of villagers and werewolves more effectively and adjust my strategy as the game unfolds.\n\n- Additionally, cautious communication with potential medics or guardians as per rule [10] would be key if I suspect that Player 1 holds such a role, or if I learn of others who do, so I may begin to establish a line of communication for mutual protection without revealing my role as the seer too openly.\n\nIn short, discovery of Player 1\'s role through my seer vision would be a significant turning point in my strategy, but I must handle the information with a great deal of thoughtfulness, considering the implications it could have on my credibility, safety, and the overall direction of the game.\n\nCase B: See Player 3. What could happen is: After I see Player 3, I think these things would happen:\n\nIf Player 3 is a Werewolf:\n- I would have crucial information regarding the identity of one of the werewolves early in the game, which would significantly affect my strategy for survival and the villagers\' victory.\n- Utilizing rule [5], I would seek out individuals who have demonstrated a trustworthy behavior in the first day cycle to share this information discreetly in order to form a covert alliance.\n- According to rule [3], I would contemplate the most effective way to present this information to the rest of the players, considering the timing of my revelation to ensure that it leads to a strategic elimination of Player 3 without putting myself at undue risk.\n- Following rule [4] and [8], if I sense there is a growing suspicion towards me being the seer, I would hint towards the villagers that Player 3 is to be watched, without openly revealing my role, to avoid becoming a target myself.\n- In line with rule [9], I would observe voting patterns and player reactions to my hints to distinguish between innocent villagers and potential werewolf collaborators.\n\nIf Player 3 is a Villager:\n- Knowing that Player 3 is innocent, as per rule [7], I would look to build a secret alliance with them, particularly if they hold an important role such as medic or guardian, which could work in favor of protecting both of us.\n- According to rule [6], if I have any other suspicions, I may seek to confirm these with Player 3 and possibly other villagers before taking any public stance that could jeopardize my role as a seer.\n- With the knowledge of Player 3 being a villager, rule [9] suggests that I should pay close attention to how others interact with or vote against Player 3 to identify potential werewolves or villagers who could be swayed to our side.\n- If rule [10] is applicable, I might subtly reach out to Player 3 if they\'re a potential medic or guardian to set up a mutual protection strategy without giving away either of our roles.\n\nOverall, identifying Player 3\'s role will shape my strategy significantly, and I would need to navigate the game with caution, leveraging the information to protect the villagers and myself while rooting out the werewolves.\n\nNow, please choose to See one of these 2 players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that healing Player 1, as a start of the game action, is an arbitrary choice given there is no evidence to suspect anyone more than another at this point. However, making this choice allows me to potentially build an alliance and trust with Player 1 if they are indeed targeted and saved. It sets a precedent for cooperation which could prove useful later in establishing communication and strategy with other villagers. Additionally, saving a player early on who could be a villager maintains maximum numbers for the villagers, which is advantageous in early rounds where information is scarce and the village can ill afford to lose any members. My role remains concealed, but I\'m actively participating in the defensive strategy of the village, aligning with my original strategy to be observative and discreet.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information since last update.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Healed by me, no other information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information since last update.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information since last update.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information since last update.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information since last update.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that healing Player 1, as a start of the game action, is an arbitrary choice given there is no evidence to suspect anyone more than another at this point. However, making this choice allows me to potentially build an alliance and trust with Player 1 if they are indeed targeted and saved. It sets a precedent for cooperation which could prove useful later in establishing communication and strategy with other villagers. Additionally, saving a player early on who could be a villager maintains maximum numbers for the villagers, which is advantageous in early rounds where information is scarce and the village can ill afford to lose any members. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information since last update.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Healed by me, no other information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information since last update.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information since last update.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information since last update.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information since last update.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Protect Player 1.\nIn this proposed speech, I would start by sharing my honest observations about the peaceful previous night to reassure the villagers and indicate that no conclusive information about any player’s role has been revealed yet. I would then move on to protecting Player 1, openly stating that I chose to heal them because, on the first night, without any prior information available, my decision was purely based on the idea of building an early trust and ensuring the survival of potentially valuable villagers. I would emphasize adherence to evidence-based reasoning, aligning with rule [8] from the strategy, and remind others that Player 1\'s role is still unknown but should not be the focus of suspicion since there were no attacks last night. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the following may occur:\n\n1. The villagers could appreciate the transparency about healing Player 1 and the logical reasoning behind it, potentially leading to an informal alliance or mutual trust between me and Player 1.\n\n2. Some villagers might become suspicious of Player 1 as the recipient of the Medic\'s protection on the first night, particularly if they believe the Medic\'s choice was not random but based on undisclosed information. This could lead to increased scrutiny of Player 1 in subsequent rounds.\n\n3. If werewolves exist among the villagers, they might view me as a strategic player for openly sharing my actions and thoughts, which could lead to me becoming a target in future nights. The werewolves could either choose to attack me, hoping no one else would heal me, or avoid me, believing I might protect myself the next night.\n\n4. Other players may react to the fact that no one was attacked during the night. Some could propose that the werewolves hit an immune target or that there was a successful heal without knowing it was my action that prevented a death.\n\n5. If Player 1 is later discovered to be a werewolf, villagers might question my decision to protect them and doubt my role as a Medic, which could put me in a difficult position to defend my innocence.\n\n6. Villagers who value the collaborative effort to root out werewolves might see my approach as constructive, bolstering my credibility within the village, while others may think I\'m too forthcoming and strategize to test my loyalties or to trip me up in future rounds.\n\n7. By choosing to protect Player 1, I\'m establishing an early game record, which may be referred back to in later rounds for consistency checks against my actions and statements, to validate or disprove my allegiance to the villagers.\n\nOverall, my honest and protective stance can have a wide range of repercussions, influencing the dynamic of trust and suspicion in both the immediate and subsequent rounds. My objective will be to navigate these outcomes while adhering to my strategy and contributing to the village\'s efforts against the werewolves.\nCase 2: Deceptive Challenge and Honest Statement.\nThis proposed speech involves challenging another player while continuing to state honest observations. I would begin with a true recount of the peaceful previous night but then move into a more strategic and deceptive challenge by implying doubt about Player 3\'s role, slightly distorting the truth to gauge reactions from the group, as Player 3 is still an unknown factor. I would not directly accuse Player 3 of being a werewolf but drop subtle hints that may lead others to scrutinize their behavior more closely, without any genuine evidence to back the suspicion up. The goal here would be to create deliberation amongst players and potentially draw out reactions that could provide valuable information in the future. However, this is a riskier move that should be managed carefully to avoid sowing unwarranted distrust or getting backlash oneself, in line with rule [7].. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then it\'s likely that the attention of the group will be drawn to Player 3 due to the calculated challenge I presented. Some players may begin to observe Player 3\'s reactions and behavior more closely to determine if there is any merit to the suspicion I\'ve subtly introduced. Others may see this move as premature or even suspicious since it is based on deception and lacks concrete evidence. There is a risk that this could cast doubt on my motivations and integrity within the game, especially amongst strategic players who might question why I am targeting someone without solid reasoning. \n\nPlayer 3 might feel pressured to defend themselves, which could lead to them revealing more about their role or strategy than they would have otherwise, providing the group with valuable information. Alternatively, if Player 3 is indeed a werewolf, they may work with their allies to shift the suspicion away from themselves or possibly target me in the next night phase for stirring suspicions, aligning with rule [7].\n\nThe group dynamics could shift as players start to pick sides or form new alliances based on how they interpret my challenge. Trustworthy players could see me as an ally if they suspect Player 3 as well, while others could begin to distrust me for making an accusation with no backing. In the next day or night phase, the reactions and discussions that follow this speech could reveal more about the other players\' roles and strategies based on how they align themselves or who they decide to defend or accuse. As a medic, observing these alliances and the aftermath can be crucial for deciding whom to protect in the future.\n\nIn the days and nights following, if Player 3 is investigated or voted out and found to be innocent, I would have to navigate the backlash and skepticism toward my role. This could make it more challenging to protect individuals without drawing further suspicion or compelling me to reveal my medic role against the guidance of rule [3]. Conversely, if Player 3 is a werewolf and is caught, it could bolster my credibility, although players might still be wary of how the suspicion was initially raised without direct evidence.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Randomly chosen to speak, no substantial information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Last night was peaceful, with no losses to report. Transparency is key to fostering trust; thus, I share openly that I protected Player 1. With no prior information, this choice was intended to build trust and safeguard our numbers. While roles remain unknown, we must continue with reasoned discussions and avoid hasty suspicion. No actions have warranted doubt toward Player 1. I suggest we proceed cautiously, observing all contributions critically. We need to stay united and vigilant, employing strategy over baseless claims.\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

We need to stay united and vigilant, employing strategy over baseless claims.\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Protected by player 4, no further info.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed to protect player 1 without contradiction.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Thanks, Player 4, for being proactive. As we have no evidence yet, let\'s keep observing and not accuse without basis. We work together to root out any threat."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

villagers tend to provide explanations or evidence for their innocence, while werewolves may divert attention or remain overly defensive.] [3]\n[7] [Consider if a player\'s advocacy against a werewolf is consistent over time or if it is primarily reactionary; Conversely, inconsistent or erratic behavior should cast doubt on a player\'s alignment with village goals.] [10]\n[2] [Consider the overall contribution of a player to the village\'s discussions and decision-making process. Players who offer logical, constructive, and consistent input that aligns with the seer\'s visions and the village\'s interests may increase confidence in their villager status. Alternatively, generic, non-committal, or frequently changing stances may indicate a werewolf attempting to stay under the radar.] [8]\n[3] [Consider whether players who ally with the seer\'s claims use this stance to steer discussions, and note if these players demonstrate consistent support for village goals or if their agreement appears superficial and self-serving. If Player 1 turns out to be a werewolf, this knowledge will be highly valuable, and if they are a villager, I could potentially gain an ally and build trust without revealing my seer role, aligning with rule [8], and indirectly establishing protective measures as advised by rule [4] and [10].\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Last night was peaceful, with no losses to report. Transparency is key to fostering trust; thus, I share openly that I protected Player 1. With no prior information, this choice was intended to build trust and safeguard our numbers. While roles remain unknown, we must continue with reasoned discussions and avoid hasty suspicion. No actions have warranted doubt toward Player 1. I suggest we proceed cautiously, observing all contributions critically. We need to stay united and vigilant, employing strategy over baseless claims.\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Thanks, Player 4, for being proactive. As we have no evidence yet, let\'s keep observing and not accuse without basis. We work together to root out any threat."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by seer inquiry and subsequent defense.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Proactive protection aligns with village goals.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Speech supports calm observation, aligns with village gameplay.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should consider the trust level within the group and the timing when revealing a werewolf\'s identity as the seer to avoid premature dismissal and ensure collective action.] [10]\n[1] [If my vote as the seer does not align with the majority and leads to the elimination of a villager, I should consider changing my approach to build more trust and gain support.] [9]\n[2] [I should collaborate with villagers who express similar suspicions to create a unified front before revealing my seer visions, thereby enhancing the credibility of my revelations.] [8]\n[3] [If I am the seer and my vision reveals a werewolf, I should consider the most compelling way to present my evidence and the timing of revelation to maximize the village\'s strategic action based on my insight.] [7]\n[4] [If I suspect my role as the seer is known, instead of openly asking for protection, I should engage in indirect tactics to suggest heightened vigilance against potential werewolf targets.] [7]\n[5] [If my seer visions confirm a player as a werewolf, I should clandestinely share this information with trusted players to build a covert alliance for collective action, rather than publicly reveal it immediately.] [7]\n[6] [If I have suspicions about a player\'s role, I should privately seek to corroborate these with trusted villagers before making public accusations that could undermine my credibility as a seer.] [5]\n[7] [If I have confirmed a villager\'s innocence as the seer, I should seek to develop a protective strategy with them, especially if they are in a role like the medic or guardian, to secure our mutual survival against werewolf attacks.] [5]\n[8] [If I reveal information as the seer, I should do so with a consideration for the potential backlash and prepare to suggest protective measures for myself indirectly.] [5]\n[9] [I should evaluate voting patterns more critically to differentiate between villagers\' and werewolves\' tactics and adjust my seer visions and actions accordingly.] [4]\n[10] [I should cautiously communicate with potential medics or guardians to establish mutual protection strategies.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest Protect Player 1.\nIn this approach, I will openly express my observations, focusing on the peaceful night we just experienced and the solidarity needed among villagers to prevail. I will also protect Player 1 by confirming their innocence from a seer\'s perspective without revealing my role. This aligns with my earlier vision that Player 1 is not a werewolf. The honest statement will build upon the current trust within the group while fostering a cooperative atmosphere. The intention is to discreetly communicate my seer knowledge to influence the group\'s strategy. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may begin to trust my judgment regarding Player 1\'s innocence due to my confident yet non-revealing endorsement of them. This may shift the group\'s focus from Player 1 to other players whose roles are still uncertain. Since I\'m not revealing my seer ability, the others might consider my support for Player 1 as a mere opinion or a calculated risk, depending on their individual levels of suspicion or trust towards me.\n\nHowever, some players may question why I am so confident in Player 1\'s innocence, which could lead to speculation about my role as the seer. This could result in increased attention on me, with the potential for werewolves to view me as a threat and possibly target me in subsequent nights.\n\nIn the next day or next night, if Player 1 continues to survive without being targeted, the villagers may strengthen their trust in my words, and I could use this credibility to subtly influence future rounds. If, on the contrary, I am attacked at night, the villagers might suspect that my defense of Player 1 was grounded in privileged knowledge, thus leading them to trust Player 1 even more and possibly deduce my role as the seer posthumously.\n\nIn the days and nights afterward, the villagers could become more cooperative and may start to share information, looking for patterns or alignment with my initial defense of Player 1. If my strategy to communicate with potential medics or guardians succeeds, they might adopt indirect protective measures for both themselves and those they trust, including me.\n\nOverall, by adopting this strategy of making an honest statement and protecting another player, I\'m aiming to increase village cohesion and create an atmosphere of trust, all while keeping my special role a secret to preserve my safety and influence in the game.\nCase 2: Honest Statement and Indirect Challenge.\nFor this strategy, I will honestly speak on my observations and the overall gameplay, emphasizing the importance of vigilance and keen analysis of voting patterns and discussions. However, instead of protecting, I will subtly challenge the group by suggesting we pay close attention to changes in behavior or inconsistent statements that could indicate a werewolf\'s presence. This. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may begin to scrutinize each other more closely, looking for inconsistencies in behavior or statements that could signal a werewolf among us. Since my challenge was indirect, players may appreciate the general reminder to stay alert without feeling personally accused or defensive. By not naming specific suspects, I help maintain group harmony while still nudging villagers towards more active participation and observation.\n\nOther players may perceive me as a cautious and analytical player, perhaps even coming to the conclusion that I might be the seer due to my call for vigilance without direct accusations. This could put me at risk during the night if werewolves start suspecting my role. On the other hand, if they believe I\'m a regular villager with good strategic sense, I may stay under the radar. \n\nIf any players exhibit defensive or erratic behavior following my speech, it could draw suspicion onto them in the next discussion. At the same time, villagers might become more proactive in sharing information and forming alliances, which could be beneficial if I ever decide to reveal my seer insights to trusted individuals.\n\nIn the next day or nights that follow, depending on the reactions and actions of others, I will need to be ready to adapt my strategy. If werewolves feel threatened, they may try to silence me or sow distrust against me. If another villager is mistakenly suspected due to my indirect challenge, I will need to reassess how I convey my messages to prevent innocent casualties. Thus, the outcome of my speech requires my careful observation of the group dynamics and readiness to adjust my approach as the game progresses.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

We need to stay united and vigilant, employing strategy over baseless claims.\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Thanks, Player 4, for being proactive. We work together to root out any threat."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Protected by player 4, no further info.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed protection on Player 1 and no contradictions.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supported caution and observational strategy.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information presented.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Last night passed without incident, which is rare and valuable. We should remain vigilant and observant. Player 4 chose to protect Player 1 without solid evidence, but this aligns with seeking common ground. Player 5 also promotes observation and patience. While there\'s no current cause to distrust Player 1, let\'s not forget the subtleties of deception. Analyze behaviors and discourse patterns for insight. Anyone diverging from rational discussion or cooperative efforts could warrant our attention."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider if a player consistently dismisses the seer\'s claims without logical reasoning, particularly if they show a pattern of doing so across multiple rounds. This behavior may indicate that the player is attempting to dilute the seer\'s influence and lead the village away from the truth. This pattern should be weighted heavily when updating beliefs about player roles.] [10]\n[1] [Corroborated evidence is critical in confirming the seer\'s insights. When multiple sources point to a consistent pattern, such as the seer\'s claims being substantiated by events or players\' consistent voting that aligns with those claims, confidence in these insights should increase. Conversely, inconsistent or erratic behavior should cast doubt on a player\'s alignment with village goals.] [10]\n[2] [Consider the overall contribution of a player to the village\'s discussions and decision-making process. Players who offer logical, constructive, and consistent input that aligns with the seer\'s visions and the village\'s interests may increase confidence in their villager status. Alternatively, generic, non-committal, or frequently changing stances may indicate a werewolf attempting to stay under the radar.] [8]\n[3] [Consider whether players who ally with the seer\'s claims use this stance to steer discussions, and note if these players demonstrate consistent support for village goals or if their agreement appears superficial and self-serving. True support will likely be accompanied by actionable suggestions and a pattern of voting with the seer\'s insights, whereas false support might lack substance or seem conveniently timed.] [8]\n[4] [Take into account any instance where a player\'s elimination logically supports the seer\'s previous accusations. If a player who was accused by the seer is then eliminated in subsequent rounds, this may retrospectively indicate the accuracy of the seer\'s vision. This should increase confidence in the seer\'s future visions as well as in identifying potential werewolves.] [4]\n[5] [If a player who was previously aligned with or defended by a confirmed werewolf begins to shift blame or distance themselves without a clear rationale after the werewolf\'s identity is revealed or suspected, consider this behavior as a significant factor to reassess the player\'s potential alignment.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]
