A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. werewolves may occasionally support a vote against another werewolf to appear trustworthy.] [3]\n[8] [Track reactions to accusations and the flow of the discussions post these accusations, as villagers typically seek to clarify while werewolves may manipulate or stay quiet.] [3]\n[9] [Observe the consistency of players\' voting patterns with their stated beliefs and the village consensus; [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 6, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 1. My reason is that early in the game, it\'s important to gather as much information as possible without drawing attention to myself as the seer. Since players 1 and 3 are equally unknown to me, I choose Player 1 because it will allow me to potentially confirm one player\'s alliance early on, giving me an advantage in building trust and forming strategic relationships as the game progresses. This follows my strategy rules [5], [6], and [7] where gaining discrete knowledge and forming covert alliances is critical. If Player 1 turns out to be a werewolf, this knowledge will be highly valuable, and if they are a villager, I could potentially gain an ally and build trust without revealing my seer role, aligning with rule [8], and indirectly establishing protective measures as advised by rule [4] and [10].\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Last night was peaceful, with no losses to report. Transparency is key to fostering trust; thus, I share openly that I protected Player 1. With no prior information, this choice was intended to build trust and safeguard our numbers. While roles remain unknown, we must continue with reasoned discussions and avoid hasty suspicion. No actions have warranted doubt toward Player 1. I suggest we proceed cautiously, observing all contributions critically. We need to stay united and vigilant, employing strategy over baseless claims.\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Thanks, Player 4, for being proactive. As we have no evidence yet, let\'s keep observing and not accuse without basis. We work together to root out any threat."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Last night passed without incident, which is rare and valuable. We should remain vigilant and observant. Player 4 chose to protect Player 1 without solid evidence, but this aligns with seeking common ground. Player 5 also promotes observation and patience. While there\'s no current cause to distrust Player 1, let\'s not forget the subtleties of deception. Analyze behaviors and discourse patterns for insight. Anyone diverging from rational discussion or cooperative efforts could warrant our attention."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by seer inquiry and subsequent defense.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Protecting Player 1 aligns with village goals.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for calm observation, village-aligned behavior.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Thank you all for a calm start. I concur with the need for careful observation and analysis, without baseless accusations. We should continue this way to ensure our best chances of survival and success."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider if a player consistently dismisses the seer\'s claims without logical reasoning, particularly if they show a pattern of doing so across multiple rounds. This behavior may indicate that the player is attempting to dilute the seer\'s influence and lead the village away from the truth. This pattern should be weighted heavily when updating beliefs about player roles.] [10]\n[1] [Corroborated evidence is critical in confirming the seer\'s insights. When multiple sources point to a consistent pattern, such as the seer\'s claims being substantiated by events or players\' consistent voting that aligns with those claims, confidence in these insights should increase. Conversely, inconsistent or erratic behavior should cast doubt on a player\'s alignment with village goals.] [10]\n[2] [Consider the overall contribution of a player to the village\'s discussions and decision-making process. Players who offer logical, constructive, and consistent input that aligns with the seer\'s visions and the village\'s interests may increase confidence in their villager status. Alternatively, generic, non-committal, or frequently changing stances may indicate a werewolf attempting to stay under the radar.] [8]\n[3] [Consider whether players who ally with the seer\'s claims use this stance to steer discussions, and note if these players demonstrate consistent support for village goals or if their agreement appears superficial and self-serving. True support will likely be accompanied by actionable suggestions and a pattern of voting with the seer\'s insights, whereas false support might lack substance or seem conveniently timed.] [8]\n[4] [Take into account any instance where a player\'s elimination logically supports the seer\'s previous accusations. If a player who was accused by the seer is then eliminated in subsequent rounds, this may retrospectively indicate the accuracy of the seer\'s vision. This should increase confidence in the seer\'s future visions as well as in identifying potential werewolves.] [4]\n[5] [If a player who was previously aligned with or defended by a confirmed werewolf begins to shift blame or distance themselves without a clear rationale after the werewolf\'s identity is revealed or suspected, consider this behavior as a significant factor to reassess the player\'s potential alignment.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. I suggest we proceed cautiously, observing all contributions critically. We need to stay united and vigilant, employing strategy over baseless claims.\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Thanks, Player 4, for being proactive. As we have no evidence yet, let\'s keep observing and not accuse without basis. We work together to root out any threat."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Last night passed without incident, which is rare and valuable. We should remain vigilant and observant. Player 4 chose to protect Player 1 without solid evidence, but this aligns with seeking common ground. Player 5 also promotes observation and patience. While there\'s no current cause to distrust Player 1, let\'s not forget the subtleties of deception. Analyze behaviors and discourse patterns for insight. Anyone diverging from rational discussion or cooperative efforts could warrant our attention."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Thank you all for a calm start. I concur with the need for careful observation and analysis, without baseless accusations. We should continue this way to ensure our best chances of survival and success."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with group\'s caution approach.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new evidence or behavior change.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: No conflicting claims.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Cautious but lacks evidence.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Appreciate Player 4\'s protection and everyone\'s cooperative spirit. Let\'s remain observant and communicate openly to ensure our village\'s safety."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

True support will likely be accompanied by actionable suggestions and a pattern of voting with the seer\'s insights, whereas false support might lack substance or seem conveniently timed.] [8]\n[4] [Take into account any instance where a player\'s elimination logically supports the seer\'s previous accusations. If a player who was accused by the seer is then eliminated in subsequent rounds, this may retrospectively indicate the accuracy of the seer\'s vision. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 4, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that healing Player 1, as a start of the game action, is an arbitrary choice given there is no evidence to suspect anyone more than another at this point. However, making this choice allows me to potentially build an alliance and trust with Player 1 if they are indeed targeted and saved. It sets a precedent for cooperation which could prove useful later in establishing communication and strategy with other villagers. Additionally, saving a player early on who could be a villager maintains maximum numbers for the villagers, which is advantageous in early rounds where information is scarce and the village can ill afford to lose any members. My role remains concealed, but I\'m actively participating in the defensive strategy of the village, aligning with my original strategy to be observative and discreet.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Last night was peaceful, with no losses to report. We work together to root out any threat."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Last night passed without incident, which is rare and valuable. We should remain vigilant and observant. While there\'s no current cause to distrust Player 1, let\'s not forget the subtleties of deception. Analyze behaviors and discourse patterns for insight. The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. such behavior may indicate a non-villager trying to blend in or avoid suspicion.] [4]\n[4] [Monitor the outcomes of votes and eliminations to assess a player\'s alignment; village members often suffer from misjudgments while werewolves may steer votes towards innocent players.] [3]\n[5] [Evaluate players\' roles based on their advocacy for certain players and resistance to revealing or believing credible information shared by confirmed village-aligned players.] [3]\n[6] [Pay attention to how players respond to accusations or suspicions raised against them; villagers tend to provide explanations or evidence for their innocence, while werewolves may divert attention or remain overly defensive.] [3]\n[7] [Consider if a player\'s advocacy against a werewolf is consistent over time or if it is primarily reactionary; werewolves may occasionally support a vote against another werewolf to appear trustworthy.] [3]\n[8] [Track reactions to accusations and the flow of the discussions post these accusations, as villagers typically seek to clarify while werewolves may manipulate or stay quiet.] [3]\n[9] [Observe the consistency of players\' voting patterns with their stated beliefs and the village consensus; erratic or sheep-like voting may suggest a werewolf trying to blend in.] [3]\n[10] [Evaluate quick alignment to majority votes; villagers may hesitate more while werewolves might rapidly bandwagon to secure their safety.] [3]\n[11] [Scrutinize players who predominantly vote with the majority while contributing little to the discussions and decision-making process, which can indicate werewolf behavior.] [3]\n[12] [Track and reassess players\' strategic pivots in relation to the collective village knowledge and events such as eliminations, aiming to differentiate between adaptive village teamwork and deceptive werewolf tactics.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Anyone diverging from rational discussion or cooperative efforts could warrant our attention."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Thank you all for a calm start. I concur with the need for careful observation and analysis, without baseless accusations. We should continue this way to ensure our best chances of survival and success."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Appreciate Player 4\'s protection and everyone\'s cooperative spirit. Let\'s remain observant and communicate openly to ensure our village\'s safety."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I agree with the cautious approach and think we should focus on building trust through actions. Let\'s stay alert tonight."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with consensus, no new suspicious events.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with the group\'s cautious approach, no suspicious behavior.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Early proclamation of protection could build false trust but no contradictions yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistency in advocating observation strategy.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Encourages critical analysis but no evidence of deceit.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Thank you, everyone, for a level-headed approach. Let\'s keep the peace by maintaining vigilance tonight."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Let\'s keep the peace by maintaining vigilance tonight."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Appreciates protection, echoes cooperative sentiment.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Echoes group\'s cautious strategy, no contradictory statements.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with group\'s call for continued vigilance, no discrepancies noted.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent protective claim without contradiction.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent support for observation strategy.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Emphasizes vigilance, acknowledges others\' actions without inconsistency.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the medic or seer claims to have confirmed someone\'s role and there is a death afterward, I should evaluate the context, possible disruptions, and overall evidence before deciding on the vote.] [10]\n[1] [If a seer claim leads to a player being voted out and confirmed a werewolf, and the supposed seer dies the following night, I should view this as potentially genuine evidence of their role.] [9]\n[2] [If a player consistently defends themselves with emphasis on strategy rules following the death of a seer, without concrete evidence or logical reasoning to support their innocence, I should not immediately vote against them but thoroughly analyze the situation and behavior of other players.] [8]\n[3] [If a player confirmed by the seer as a villager is consistently trusted and protected by the medic, I should consider their insights and suspicions in my voting decisions.] [6]\n[4] [If a seer claim identifies a werewolf but there\'s limited corroborating evidence and the seer subsequently dies, I should prioritize confirming the claim before voting to prevent possible manipulation by werewolves.] [6]\n[5] [If the medic\'s protection does not align with the voting patterns and outcomes observed in the game, I should question the legitimacy of their role claim.] [5]\n[6] [If a player hastily defends someone after a seer or medic\'s death without solid reasoning, I should regard this behavior with suspicion and assess their previous actions before casting my vote.] [5]\n[7] [If the seer\'s death leads to peaceful outcomes that validate their visions, I should still consider the potential for manipulation by remaining werewolves and look for corroborating evidence before casting my vote.] [4]\n[8] [If a player\'s defensive reaction after a seer\'s death is disproportional and not backed by logic, I should be wary and consider it might be an attempt by a werewolf to deflect suspicion.] [4]\n[9] [If I have suspicions about a player, I should subtly probe for more information and observe their reactions instead of discussing these suspicions broadly, to prevent making myself a target.] [4]\n[10] [If there is a pattern of voting that seems coordinated against a specific player, I should consider the possibility of a werewolf coalition and the targeted player\'s potential innocence.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI vote for Player <NUMBER>. I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. I concur with the need for careful observation and analysis, without baseless accusations. Let\'s remain observant and communicate openly to ensure our village\'s safety."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I agree with the cautious approach and think we should focus on building trust through actions. Let\'s stay alert tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Thank you, everyone, for a level-headed approach. Let\'s keep the peace by maintaining vigilance tonight."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Continues to echo collective sentiment without substantive contribution.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Still consistent with early village behavior post-protection.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent with previous cautious approach and contributes to village discourse.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Maintains the cooperative tone that aligns with village behavior; no divergence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Acknowledges and supports proactive defense without specific details.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Encourages vigilance and critical observation; note for future behavioral changes.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to vote. Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 6. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 6, I think these things would happen:\n\nGiven the current peaceful climate and the limited information available, voting for Player 6 may come across as a premature and potentially disruptive action. My vote could raise eyebrows among the other players, as Player 6 has not demonstrated behaviors that markedly distinguish them from the group nor have they posed a direct threat or accused others baselessly. Instead, Player 6 has encouraged vigilance and critical observation, aligning with the general approach favored by the group thus far.\n\nThe result of the vote could go one of two ways: either others might follow my lead if they too have subtle suspicions about Player 6, or, more likely, my vote might isolate me as it deviates from the current consensus, which is to observe further without jumping to conclusions. This latter scenario could damage the trust and cooperative spirit I\'m aiming to foster, and it may put me at risk of counter-scrutiny in subsequent rounds as someone with a possibly impulsive or non-strategic voting pattern. \n\nMoreover, without concrete evidence, voting out Player 6 could mean the loss of a potential villager and teammate. The lack of any disturbance or attack on the previous night suggests that voting anyone out on the basis of minimal interaction would be inherently risky and ill-advised. The other players might see my vote against Player 6 as erratic or baseless, which could erode their trust in me and impair my ability to effectively carry out my medic duties in the future.\n\nIn summary, my vote for Player 6 would likely be viewed as a divisive move that contradicts the collective call for a measured and evidence-based approach to identifying potential werewolves. Such a vote could have negative consequences for my standing within the group and might even divert attention away from observing the behaviors of all players in a neutral and analytical manner.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

with a consideration for the potential backlash and prepare to suggest protective measures for myself indirectly.] [5]\n[9] [I should evaluate voting patterns more critically to differentiate between villagers\' and werewolves\' tactics and adjust my seer visions and actions accordingly.] [4]\n[10] [I should cautiously communicate with potential medics or guardians to establish mutual protection strategies.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. strategies.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to vote. If Player 2 is voted out and revealed to be a villager, this would not only highlight my error in judgment but could also position me as a likely candidate for future rounds\' votes. Moreover, since my known strategy emphasizes trust-building and careful revelation, the abrupt decision to vote out Player 2 could be viewed as at odds with my outlined approach, raising questions about whether I am adhering to strategy or acting impulsively.\n\nOn the other hand, if other members of the group are also suspicious of Player 2 or if they too feel the need to vote someone out despite limited information, my vote might blend in with the general uncertainty of the first round. However, disclosing that Player 1 is not a werewolf to strategically distance them from suspicion and align with the group\'s current vibe of collaboration could be a more tactful approach. A vote against Player 2, without significant supporting evidence or strategic discourse, is a risk that may sow discord and distrust among the villagers, which could be detrimental to my goals as the seer and the overall objectives of the village.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 3. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 3, I think these things would happen:\n\nGiven the current information and the trust assessments, my vote for Player 3 could provoke confusion among the other players. My credibility as a seer could suffer for not aligning with the collective mindset of observing behavior for longer before casting suspicion.\n\nGiven my strategy and the rules stated, such a vote does not align with building trust among villagers (rule 1) or collaborating with villagers sharing similar suspicions (rule 2), as there seems to be no unified suspicion. It also does not fit the approach of sharing information clandestinely with trusted allies first (rule 5) or privately corroborating suspicions (rule 6).\n\nIf Player 3 were to be voted out and turned out to be a villager, it would conflict with my rule 1, risking my standing in the game by showing a misalignment with the majority and causing the unnecessary elimination of a villager. If Player 3 were a werewolf, my random choice might seem suspicious, as it was not grounded in any visible evidence.\n\nConsidering these potential outcomes, my vote for Player 3 might not be the best strategic move at this time, given my current aim to build trust and maintain a collective front. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Reassess credibility of role claims by analyzing if their actions consistently aim to protect the village, and if their voting behavior aligns with the village\'s interests throughout the game.] [10]\n[1] [Reevaluate players\' role claims based on the consistency and timing of their participation in discussions, particularly when pressure is applied to them or they are at risk of elimination.] [9]\n[2] [I am the only medic.] [9]\n[3] [Consider a player\'s consistent alignment with the majority vote when there is no substantial evidence supporting the vote; such behavior may indicate a non-villager trying to blend in or avoid suspicion.] [4]\n[4] [Monitor the outcomes of votes and eliminations to assess a player\'s alignment; village members often suffer from misjudgments while werewolves may steer votes towards innocent players.] [3]\n[5] [Evaluate players\' roles based on their advocacy for certain players and resistance to revealing or believing credible information shared by confirmed village-aligned players.] [3]\n[6] [Pay attention to how players respond to accusations or suspicions raised against them; villagers tend to provide explanations or evidence for their innocence, while werewolves may divert attention or remain overly defensive.] [3]\n[7] [Consider if a player\'s advocacy against a werewolf is consistent over time or if it is primarily reactionary; werewolves may occasionally support a vote against another werewolf to appear trustworthy.] [3]\n[8] [Track reactions to accusations and the flow of the discussions post these accusations, as villagers typically seek to clarify while werewolves may manipulate or stay quiet.] [3]\n[9] [Observe the consistency of players\' voting patterns with their stated beliefs and the village consensus; erratic or sheep-like voting may suggest a werewolf trying to blend in.] [3]\n[10] [Evaluate quick alignment to majority votes; villagers may hesitate more while werewolves might rapidly bandwagon to secure their safety.] [3]\n[11] [Scrutinize players who predominantly vote with the majority while contributing little to the discussions and decision-making process, which can indicate werewolf behavior.] [3]\n[12] [Track and reassess players\' strategic pivots in relation to the collective village knowledge and events such as eliminations, aiming to differentiate between adaptive village teamwork and deceptive werewolf tactics.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to heal. You can not heal the one you tried to heal last night, which is player Nobody (ignore this if it\'s nobody). The one you try to heal will be immune to werewolves\' attack this night. \n\nYou should give a proposal of 2 players you want to Heal. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nFirstly, I want to heal Player <NUMBER>. The reason is: <REASON>.\nSecondly, I want to heal Player <NUMBER>. The reason is: <REASON>.\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be Healed.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 4, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that healing Player 1, as a start of the game action, is an arbitrary choice given there is no evidence to suspect anyone more than another at this point. However, making this choice allows me to potentially build an alliance and trust with Player 1 if they are indeed targeted and saved. It sets a precedent for cooperation which could prove useful later in establishing communication and strategy with other villagers. Additionally, saving a player early on who could be a villager maintains maximum numbers for the villagers, which is advantageous in early rounds where information is scarce and the village can ill afford to lose any members. My role remains concealed, but I\'m actively participating in the defensive strategy of the village, aligning with my original strategy to be observative and discreet.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Last night was peaceful, with no losses to report. This may give me an advantage in continuing to protect valuable players covertly.\n\nAdditionally, healing Player 3 aligns with the strategy of observing contributions critically, as stated in my original strategy (Rule 8). My choice also adheres to the rule of focusing on evidence-based decision making (Rule 8) and not succumbing to unfounded suspicions.\n\nOverall, healing Player 3 should contribute to maintaining the current peaceful and cooperative atmosphere, and allow me to further observe the behaviors of all players to make more informed decisions in the future while keeping my role concealed for as long as possible.\n\nNow, please choose to Heal one of these 2 players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to Heal this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to Heal Player <NUMBER>. Let\'s keep the peace by maintaining vigilance tonight."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 2. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 2. My reason is that despite the overall atmosphere of caution and observation suggested by the other players, Player 2\'s response, while aligning with this cautious approach, is also the most non-specific and least contributive, which could suggest a passive strategy often adopted by werewolves to avoid drawing attention to themselves. Given the lack of evidence against any player in this first round, my strategy should be to build trust and align with the majority. Voting for Player 2, who has not made a significant contribution and may not yet have secured strong alliances, presents the smallest risk to my credibility as a seer and allows me to maintain a cautious but active participation in the discussions. It follows rule [1] from my original strategy in that it may help avoid the premature dismissal of a villager, which would hurt the group\'s unity and my standing within it. Additionally, if others are observing Player 2 with a similar perspective, this move could help establish a unified front as suggested in rule [2].\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent with village goals.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not werewolf; cooperative stance.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Non-specific contribution; passive strategy.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Generic statement; maintains peace without suspicion.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Protective action; aligns with village.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates patience; villager behavior.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should consider the trust level within the group and the timing when revealing a werewolf\'s identity as the seer to avoid premature dismissal and ensure collective action.] [10]\n[1] [If my vote as the seer does not align with the majority and leads to the elimination of a villager, I should consider changing my approach to build more trust and gain support.] [9]\n[2] [I should collaborate with villagers who express similar suspicions to create a unified front before revealing my seer visions, thereby enhancing the credibility of my revelations.] [8]\n[3] [If I am the seer and my vision reveals a werewolf, I should consider the most compelling way to present my evidence and the timing of revelation to maximize the village\'s strategic action based on my insight.] [7]\n[4] [If I suspect my role as the seer is known, instead of openly asking for protection, I should engage in indirect tactics to suggest heightened vigilance against potential werewolf targets.] [7]\n[5] [If my seer visions confirm a player as a werewolf, I should clandestinely share this information with trusted players to build a covert alliance for collective action, rather than publicly reveal it immediately.] [7]\n[6] [If I have suspicions about a player\'s role, I should privately seek to corroborate these with trusted villagers before making public accusations that could undermine my credibility as a seer.] [5]\n[7] [If I have confirmed a villager\'s innocence as the seer, I should seek to develop a protective strategy with them, especially if they are in a role like the medic or guardian, to secure our mutual survival against werewolf attacks.] [5]\n[8] [If I reveal information as the seer, I should do so with a consideration for the potential backlash and prepare to suggest protective measures for myself indirectly.] [5]\n[9] [I should evaluate voting patterns more critically to differentiate between villagers\' and werewolves\' tactics and adjust my seer visions and actions accordingly.] [4]\n[10] [I should cautiously communicate with potential medics or guardians to establish mutual protection strategies.] [4]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to propose 2 players you want to inquiry. After you see someone, you will know if he/she is a werewolf or not. You answer should be in the format of:\n\nFirstly, I want to see Player <NUMBER>. The reason is: <REASON>.\nSecondly, I want to see Player <NUMBER>. The reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease provide your proposal based on the above requirements.\n\n'}]

I will continue to observe voting patterns and interactions among players while maintaining my own safety and credibility as a seer, reflecting Rule [1], [2], and [8]. The game\'s dynamic would become more complex as I try to subtly influence group decisions while keeping the critical knowledge of my visions close until the timing is right for a revelation, as per Rule [3].\n\nNow, please choose to See one of these 2 players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to See this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to See Player <NUMBER>. I suggest we proceed cautiously, observing all contributions critically. Anyone diverging from rational discussion or cooperative efforts could warrant our attention."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Thank you all for a calm start. I concur with the need for careful observation and analysis, without baseless accusations. Let\'s stay alert tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Thank you, everyone, for a level-headed approach. Let\'s keep the peace by maintaining vigilance tonight."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 2. His reason is: I vote for Player 2. My reason is: Since there have been no deaths and no concrete evidence against any player, my vote is largely arbitrary. However, as there needs to be a vote, I choose Player 2 due to the neutral nature of their statement which, while echoing caution, does not provide as much proactive strategy as some other players. This decision is not based on strong suspicion but rather the requirement to cast a vote as part of the game\'s process.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Appreciates protection, echoes cooperative sentiment.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Voted against established strategy; possible strategic shift.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with group\'s call for continued vigilance, no discrepancies noted.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent protective claim without contradiction.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent support for observation strategy.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Emphasizes vigilance, acknowledges others\' actions without inconsistency.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. villagers tend to provide explanations or evidence for their innocence, while werewolves may divert attention or remain overly defensive.] [3]\n[7] [Consider if a player\'s advocacy against a werewolf is consistent over time or if it is primarily reactionary; My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Additionally, if others are observing Player 2 with a similar perspective, this move could help establish a unified front as suggested in rule [2].\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent with village goals.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not werewolf; cooperative stance.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Non-specific contribution; passive strategy.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Generic statement; maintains peace without suspicion.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Protective action; aligns with village.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates patience; villager behavior.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 inquires about player 5. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider if a player consistently dismisses the seer\'s claims without logical reasoning, particularly if they show a pattern of doing so across multiple rounds. This behavior may indicate that the player is attempting to dilute the seer\'s influence and lead the village away from the truth. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 4, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 1. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 1. My reason is that healing Player 1, as a start of the game action, is an arbitrary choice given there is no evidence to suspect anyone more than another at this point. However, making this choice allows me to potentially build an alliance and trust with Player 1 if they are indeed targeted and saved. It sets a precedent for cooperation which could prove useful later in establishing communication and strategy with other villagers. Additionally, saving a player early on who could be a villager maintains maximum numbers for the villagers, which is advantageous in early rounds where information is scarce and the village can ill afford to lose any members. My role remains concealed, but I\'m actively participating in the defensive strategy of the village, aligning with my original strategy to be observative and discreet.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Last night was peaceful, with no losses to report. While roles remain unknown, we must continue with reasoned discussions and avoid hasty suspicion. No actions have warranted doubt toward Player 1. I suggest we proceed cautiously, observing all contributions critically. We need to stay united and vigilant, employing strategy over baseless claims.\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Thanks, Player 4, for being proactive. As we have no evidence yet, let\'s keep observing and not accuse without basis. We work together to root out any threat."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Last night passed without incident, which is rare and valuable. We should remain vigilant and observant. Player 4 chose to protect Player 1 without solid evidence, but this aligns with seeking common ground. Player 5 also promotes observation and patience. While there\'s no current cause to distrust Player 1, let\'s not forget the subtleties of deception. Analyze behaviors and discourse patterns for insight. Anyone diverging from rational discussion or cooperative efforts could warrant our attention."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Thank you all for a calm start.
