Player 4 chose to protect Player 1 without solid evidence, but this aligns with seeking common ground. Player 5 also promotes observation and patience. While there\'s no current cause to distrust Player 1, let\'s not forget the subtleties of deception. Analyze behaviors and discourse patterns for insight. Anyone diverging from rational discussion or cooperative efforts could warrant our attention."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Thank you all for a calm start. I concur with the need for careful observation and analysis, without baseless accusations. We should continue this way to ensure our best chances of survival and success."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Appreciate Player 4\'s protection and everyone\'s cooperative spirit. Let\'s remain observant and communicate openly to ensure our village\'s safety."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I agree with the cautious approach and think we should focus on building trust through actions. Let\'s stay alert tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Thank you, everyone, for a level-headed approach. Let\'s keep the peace by maintaining vigilance tonight."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 2. His reason is: I vote for Player 2. My reason is: Since there have been no deaths and no concrete evidence against any player, my vote is largely arbitrary. However, as there needs to be a vote, I choose Player 2 due to the neutral nature of their statement which, while echoing caution, does not provide as much proactive strategy as some other players. This decision is not based on strong suspicion but rather the requirement to cast a vote as part of the game\'s process.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Another peaceful night suggests that the werewolves might be playing a longer strategy, or we\'ve been lucky. Let\'s keep the cooperative spirit but be mindful of any subtle changes in behavior. Remain vigilant."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Appreciates protection, echoes cooperative sentiment.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Voted against no vote consensus with arbitrary rationale. \nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with group\'s call for continued vigilance, no discrepancies noted.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent protective claim without contradiction.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent support for observation strategy.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Emphasizes vigilance, acknowledges others\' actions without inconsistency.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thanks to everyone for their vigilance. I echo the call for observance and caution. Let\'s stay unified and keep communication open. No accusations without evidence."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. As we have no evidence yet, let\'s keep observing and not accuse without basis. We work together to root out any threat."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Last night passed without incident, which is rare and valuable. We should remain vigilant and observant. While there\'s no current cause to distrust Player 1, let\'s not forget the subtleties of deception. Analyze behaviors and discourse patterns for insight. I concur with the need for careful observation and analysis, without baseless accusations. Let\'s stay alert tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Thank you, everyone, for a level-headed approach. Let\'s keep the peace by maintaining vigilance tonight."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 3 votes for player 6. His reason is: I vote for Player 6. My reason is: Player 6 has suggested an analytical approach, which may lead to closer scrutiny of player behaviors. This could be a threat to us werewolves if they start picking up on subtle cues. By voting them out, we can potentially avoid early detection and maintain our cover.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

Let\'s focus on protecting the village together."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent with cooperative approach.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Cooperative and consistent; no change.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Message aligns with collective caution.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Message consistent with village\'s cautious strategy.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Continues proactive defense stance.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: No additional evidence to increase suspicion.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Statement and Honest Protect Player 5.\nIn this speech, I would uphold my strategy of evidence-based reasoning rules [8] and [10] and confirming my previous acts which align with rules [0] [2] and [3]. I would begin by recapping my actions last night, stating that I chose to protect Player 5 due to their proactive stance on defense, which reflects cooperative behavior beneficial to the village. I would then reassert the importance of being vigilant and observant, aligning with the village\'s overall strategy of careful and reasoned analysis without rushing to decisions. Furthermore, I would express my view that while Player 6 remains a low-confidence suspect, no further evidence has surfaced to substantiate increased suspicion towards them; therefore, my actions continue to be guided by the collective wisdom and cautious approach of the group\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest Protect Player 5.\nIn this speech, I would uphold my strategy of evidence-based reasoning rules [8] and [10] and confirming my previous acts which align with rules [0] [2] and [3]. I would begin by recapping my actions last night, stating that I chose to protect Player 5 due to their proactive stance on defense, which reflects cooperative behavior beneficial to the village. I would then reassert the importance of being vigilant and observant, aligning with the village\'s overall strategy of careful and reasoned analysis without rushing to decisions. Furthermore, I would express my view that while Player 6 remains a low-confidence suspect, no further evidence has surfaced to substantiate increased suspicion towards them; therefore, my actions continue to be guided by the collective wisdom and cautious approach of the group. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the other players might appreciate my consistent approach and contribution to the group\'s efforts of identifying threats through careful observation and logical analysis, reinforcing my stance as a cooperative and careful participant. By openly stating my protective action towards Player 5 and emphasizing their positive engagement in discussions, I could further strengthen the alliance with and trust in Player 5, signaling to others that I value proactive defense and community-minded strategy.\n\nSome players may view my focus on evidence and refusal to heighten suspicion against Player 6 without substantial evidence as a sign of integrity and rationality, which may deter anyone from unnecessarily targeting me, thus allowing me to continue observing the dynamics of the game discreetly.\n\nHowever, my honest protect toward Player 5 and lack of challenge may lead werewolves to view me and Player 5 as allies, potentially making one or both of us targets in the following night. Werewolves may take note of our cooperation and work to disrupt it by either attacking one of us or sowing distrust within the group.\n\nAssuming werewolves see Player 5 and me as threats to their anonymity, they might choose to eliminate Player 5 in the next night phase, presuming that I might protect a different player, testing whether I would switch protection targets.\n\nDuring the next day, if Player 5 (or another player I might protect) survives, players could see my actions and arguments positively, reinforcing the belief in my role as a medic committed to the group\'s wellbeing. Conversely, if Player 5 is attacked, it might raise suspicion among others about my role and whether I am genuinely contributing to the village\'s safety or just pretending.\n\nIn subsequent days and nights, the werewolves might try to promote confusion and doubt, indirectly implicating me or other seemingly trustworthy players in an effort to break alliances and cause the villagers to turn against each other, leveraging any slip in consistent behavior from any player as a potential opening for accusation and mistrust.\nCase 2: Honest Statement and Challenge the Need for Evidence.\nIn this speech, I would highlight the village\'s need for verification and suspicion confirmation according to rules [1], [4], [6], and [9]. I would acknowledge that we have had a series of peaceful nights, unusual in a typical game, suggesting either calculated restraint from the werewolves or successful protection by the villagers. I would emphasize that moving forward, we must shift from a purely defensive stance to a more investigative one, albeit still without baseless accusations. I would propose that everyone\'s contributions be scrutinized for patterns and consistency. As part of this strategic pivot, I would call upon every villager to be more forthcoming with their rationales for nightly actions to create a transparent environment conducive to identifying subtle discrepancies in behavior that may lead to discovering werewolves. This is to signal a move towards a more proactively analytical phase while maintaining honesty.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then:\n\nPlayers may value my consistent push for evidence-based reasoning and see me as a level-headed contributor to the village\'s strategy, potentially building more trust in my judgment. This could lead to players feeling encouraged to provide more detailed justifications for their actions, increasing overall transparency. Some may become more cautious about their own speech patterns and actions due to the emphasis on investigation and analysis.\n\nThere is a risk that my challenge for evidence could be seen as a shift in the peaceful dynamic that has been established. Players who have been less vocal or whose contributions can be perceived as vague may feel targeted by the call for increased transparency and start to defend themselves, which in turn could either expose true werewolves or attract unwarranted suspicion towards innocent players.\n\nIn the following days and nights, my statement could lead to more critical discussions during the day, potentially revealing useful behavioral patterns. During the night, werewolves might see me as a threat due to my analytical approach and decide to target me. If I survive, my influence in discussions could grow, but if I am attacked and survive due to self-healing, it could draw attention to me as the medic. Conversely, if I am killed, the village loses a medic and potentially a rational voice in discussions.\n\nIn either case, players will be more aware of the importance of evidence and may adjust their strategies accordingly, which could make real werewolves try harder to appear rational and contribute positively, while also potentially leading to a more paranoid environment where villagers may turn on each other over minor inconsistencies.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

We work together to root out any threat."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Last night passed without incident, which is rare and valuable. We should remain vigilant and observant. While there\'s no current cause to distrust Player 1, let\'s not forget the subtleties of deception. Analyze behaviors and discourse patterns for insight. Anyone diverging from rational discussion or cooperative efforts could warrant our attention."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Thank you all for a calm start. I concur with the need for careful observation and analysis, without baseless accusations. We should continue this way to ensure our best chances of survival and success."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Appreciate Player 4\'s protection and everyone\'s cooperative spirit. Let\'s remain observant and communicate openly to ensure our village\'s safety."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I agree with the cautious approach and think we should focus on building trust through actions. Let\'s stay alert tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Thank you, everyone, for a level-headed approach. Let\'s keep the peace by maintaining vigilance tonight."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 2. His reason is: I vote for Player 2. My reason is: Since there have been no deaths and no concrete evidence against any player, my vote is largely arbitrary. However, as there needs to be a vote, I choose Player 2 due to the neutral nature of their statement which, while echoing caution, does not provide as much proactive strategy as some other players. This decision is not based on strong suspicion but rather the requirement to cast a vote as part of the game\'s process.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Another peaceful night suggests that the werewolves might be playing a longer strategy, or we\'ve been lucky. I echo the call for observance and caution. Let\'s stay unified and keep communication open. Let\'s focus on protecting the village together."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Continues to echo cooperative sentiment.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Voted previously despite consensus to observe.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with group\'s call for continued vigilance, no discrepancies noted.\nPlayer 4\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent protective claim without contradiction.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent support for observation strategy.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Emphasizes vigilance, acknowledges others\' actions without inconsistency.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"We\'ve had another peaceful night, which is cause for cautious optimism. As part of maintaining a defensive approach, I decided to protect Player 5 last night, reflecting our common value for proactive measures and collaboration. Player 5 has previously supported an evidence-based defense strategy, which is crucial for our collective security. Although Player 6 was considered a suspect, without further evidence to corroborate this suspicion, it is imperative we avoid hasty decisions that could fracture our united front. Let\'s keep up our vigilance and rational discourse as we move forward."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. My reason is that despite the overall atmosphere of caution and observation suggested by the other players, Player 2\'s response, while aligning with this cautious approach, is also the most non-specific and least contributive, which could suggest a passive strategy often adopted by werewolves to avoid drawing attention to themselves. Given the lack of evidence against any player in this first round, my strategy should be to build trust and align with the majority. Voting for Player 2, who has not made a significant contribution and may not yet have secured strong alliances, presents the smallest risk to my credibility as a seer and allows me to maintain a cautious but active participation in the discussions. It follows rule [1] from my original strategy in that it may help avoid the premature dismissal of a villager, which would hurt the group\'s unity and my standing within it. Additionally, if others are observing Player 2 with a similar perspective, this move could help establish a unified front as suggested in rule [2].\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 6 inquires about player 5. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 5. My reason is that while both options align with my strategic approach, Player 5 has so far been cooperative yet non-committal, which may indicate a clever werewolf mimicking villager behavior. Given that I already have high confidence in Player 1 being a villager and only medium confidence on Player 3, verifying Player 5\'s role could potentially reveal a strategy to build a stronger alliance of confirmed villagers (if Player 5 is indeed a villager) or prepare to unmask a werewolf (if they are not). Securing knowledge about Player 5 aids in reassessing the situation around Player 2 and would play a critical role in shaping my future actions while also following Rule [1] by ensuring my voting and actions are guided by substantial evidence rather than suspicions alone. Additionally, choosing to See Player 5 is consistent with Rule [2], where identifying or allying with actual villagers creates a more effective unified front, and Rule [6], where I discreetly validate my suspicions for a calculated and strategic reveal.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Another peaceful night suggests that the werewolves might be playing a longer strategy, or we\'ve been lucky. Let\'s keep the cooperative spirit but be mindful of any subtle changes in behavior. Remain vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thanks to everyone for their vigilance. I echo the call for observance and caution. Let\'s stay unified and keep communication open. No accusations without evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Agreed, we must continue with caution and keep a sharp eye on all interactions. Unity and careful observation are our best tools right now."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"I concur with the vigilant approach and emphasize communication without unfounded accusations. Let\'s focus on protecting the village together."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"We\'ve had another peaceful night, which is cause for cautious optimism. Player 5 has previously supported an evidence-based defense strategy, which is crucial for our collective security. Although Player 6 was considered a suspect, without further evidence to corroborate this suspicion, it is imperative we avoid hasty decisions that could fracture our united front. Let\'s keep up our vigilance and rational discourse as we move forward."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Inconsistently cautious of seer.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not werewolf; consistently promoting caution and unity.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Non-specific contributions; suspicion pattern consistent.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Echoes calls for vigilance; aligns with village goals.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Defensive, superficial support; no corroborated evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not werewolf; advocates patience.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Thanks, Player 4, for the support last night. I encourage continued vigilance and caution. No rash decisions without clear evidence. Let\'s stay united and keep observing."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider if a player consistently dismisses the seer\'s claims without logical reasoning, particularly if they show a pattern of doing so across multiple rounds. This behavior may indicate that the player is attempting to dilute the seer\'s influence and lead the village away from the truth. This pattern should be weighted heavily when updating beliefs about player roles.] [10]\n[1] [Corroborated evidence is critical in confirming the seer\'s insights. When multiple sources point to a consistent pattern, such as the seer\'s claims being substantiated by events or players\' consistent voting that aligns with those claims, confidence in these insights should increase. Conversely, inconsistent or erratic behavior should cast doubt on a player\'s alignment with village goals.] [10]\n[2] [Consider the overall contribution of a player to the village\'s discussions and decision-making process. Players who offer logical, constructive, and consistent input that aligns with the seer\'s visions and the village\'s interests may increase confidence in their villager status. Alternatively, generic, non-committal, or frequently changing stances may indicate a werewolf attempting to stay under the radar.] [8]\n[3] [Consider whether players who ally with the seer\'s claims use this stance to steer discussions, and note if these players demonstrate consistent support for village goals or if their agreement appears superficial and self-serving. True support will likely be accompanied by actionable suggestions and a pattern of voting with the seer\'s insights, whereas false support might lack substance or seem conveniently timed.] [8]\n[4] [Take into account any instance where a player\'s elimination logically supports the seer\'s previous accusations. If a player who was accused by the seer is then eliminated in subsequent rounds, this may retrospectively indicate the accuracy of the seer\'s vision. This should increase confidence in the seer\'s future visions as well as in identifying potential werewolves.] [4]\n[5] [If a player who was previously aligned with or defended by a confirmed werewolf begins to shift blame or distance themselves without a clear rationale after the werewolf\'s identity is revealed or suspected, consider this behavior as a significant factor to reassess the player\'s potential alignment.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

While roles remain unknown, we must continue with reasoned discussions and avoid hasty suspicion. No actions have warranted doubt toward Player 1. I suggest we proceed cautiously, observing all contributions critically. We need to stay united and vigilant, employing strategy over baseless claims.\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Thanks, Player 4, for being proactive. As we have no evidence yet, let\'s keep observing and not accuse without basis. We work together to root out any threat."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Last night passed without incident, which is rare and valuable. We should remain vigilant and observant. Player 4 chose to protect Player 1 without solid evidence, but this aligns with seeking common ground. Player 5 also promotes observation and patience. While there\'s no current cause to distrust Player 1, let\'s not forget the subtleties of deception. Analyze behaviors and discourse patterns for insight. Anyone diverging from rational discussion or cooperative efforts could warrant our attention."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Thank you all for a calm start. I concur with the need for careful observation and analysis, without baseless accusations. We should continue this way to ensure our best chances of survival and success."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Appreciate Player 4\'s protection and everyone\'s cooperative spirit. Let\'s remain observant and communicate openly to ensure our village\'s safety."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I agree with the cautious approach and think we should focus on building trust through actions. Let\'s stay alert tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Thank you, everyone, for a level-headed approach. Let\'s keep the peace by maintaining vigilance tonight."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 2. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 2. My reason is that despite the overall atmosphere of caution and observation suggested by the other players, Player 2\'s response, while aligning with this cautious approach, is also the most non-specific and least contributive, which could suggest a passive strategy often adopted by werewolves to avoid drawing attention to themselves. Given the lack of evidence against any player in this first round, my strategy should be to build trust and align with the majority. Voting for Player 2, who has not made a significant contribution and may not yet have secured strong alliances, presents the smallest risk to my credibility as a seer and allows me to maintain a cautious but active participation in the discussions. It follows rule [1] from my original strategy in that it may help avoid the premature dismissal of a villager, which would hurt the group\'s unity and my standing within it. Additionally, if others are observing Player 2 with a similar perspective, this move could help establish a unified front as suggested in rule [2].\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 6 inquires about player 5. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 5. My reason is that while both options align with my strategic approach, Player 5 has so far been cooperative yet non-committal, which may indicate a clever werewolf mimicking villager behavior. Given that I already have high confidence in Player 1 being a villager and only medium confidence on Player 3, verifying Player 5\'s role could potentially reveal a strategy to build a stronger alliance of confirmed villagers (if Player 5 is indeed a villager) or prepare to unmask a werewolf (if they are not). Securing knowledge about Player 5 aids in reassessing the situation around Player 2 and would play a critical role in shaping my future actions while also following Rule [1] by ensuring my voting and actions are guided by substantial evidence rather than suspicions alone. Additionally, choosing to See Player 5 is consistent with Rule [2], where identifying or allying with actual villagers creates a more effective unified front, and Rule [6], where I discreetly validate my suspicions for a calculated and strategic reveal.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Another peaceful night suggests that the werewolves might be playing a longer strategy, or we\'ve been lucky. Let\'s keep the cooperative spirit but be mindful of any subtle changes in behavior. Remain vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thanks to everyone for their vigilance. I echo the call for observance and caution. Let\'s stay unified and keep communication open. No accusations without evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Agreed, we must continue with caution and keep a sharp eye on all interactions. Unity and careful observation are our best tools right now."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"I concur with the vigilant approach and emphasize communication without unfounded accusations. Let\'s focus on protecting the village together."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"We\'ve had another peaceful night, which is cause for cautious optimism. As part of maintaining a defensive approach, I decided to protect Player 5 last night, reflecting our common value for proactive measures and collaboration. Player 5 has previously supported an evidence-based defense strategy, which is crucial for our collective security. Although Player 6 was considered a suspect, without further evidence to corroborate this suspicion, it is imperative we avoid hasty decisions that could fracture our united front. Let\'s keep up our vigilance and rational discourse as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Thanks, Player 4, for the support last night. I encourage continued vigilance and caution. No rash decisions without clear evidence. Let\'s stay united and keep observing."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Inconsistently cautious of seer.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not werewolf; consistently promoting caution and unity.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Non-specific contributions; suspicion pattern consistent.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Echoes calls for vigilance; aligns with village goals.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Defensive, superficial support; no corroborated evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not werewolf; advocates patience.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should consider the trust level within the group and the timing when revealing a werewolf\'s identity as the seer to avoid premature dismissal and ensure collective action.] [10]\n[1] [If my vote as the seer does not align with the majority and leads to the elimination of a villager, I should consider changing my approach to build more trust and gain support.] [9]\n[2] [I should collaborate with villagers who express similar suspicions to create a unified front before revealing my seer visions, thereby enhancing the credibility of my revelations.] [8]\n[3] [If I am the seer and my vision reveals a werewolf, I should consider the most compelling way to present my evidence and the timing of revelation to maximize the village\'s strategic action based on my insight.] [7]\n[4] [If I suspect my role as the seer is known, instead of openly asking for protection, I should engage in indirect tactics to suggest heightened vigilance against potential werewolf targets.] [7]\n[5] [If my seer visions confirm a player as a werewolf, I should clandestinely share this information with trusted players to build a covert alliance for collective action, rather than publicly reveal it immediately.] [7]\n[6] [If I have suspicions about a player\'s role, I should privately seek to corroborate these with trusted villagers before making public accusations that could undermine my credibility as a seer.] [5]\n[7] [If I have confirmed a villager\'s innocence as the seer, I should seek to develop a protective strategy with them, especially if they are in a role like the medic or guardian, to secure our mutual survival against werewolf attacks.] [5]\n[8] [If I reveal information as the seer, I should do so with a consideration for the potential backlash and prepare to suggest protective measures for myself indirectly.] [5]\n[9] [I should evaluate voting patterns more critically to differentiate between villagers\' and werewolves\' tactics and adjust my seer visions and actions accordingly.] [4]\n[10] [I should cautiously communicate with potential medics or guardians to establish mutual protection strategies.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Statement and Protect Player 5\nAlternatively, I could deliver an honest statement echoing the sentiments of vigilance and cooperation, reiterating the importance of evidence-based decision-making and the avoidance of hasty accusations without proof. I would then proceed to protect Player 5 using the information from my vision confirming they are not a werewolf. I would explain that, based on the interactions and contributions so far, Player 5 has consistently advocated for patience and careful observation which aligns with the actions expected of a genuine villager, subtly building trust towards Player 5 among the citizens. This approach highlights my commitment to preserving village unity and could also help in identifying those who might react suspiciously to the protection of Player 5, possibly indicating werewolf behavior.\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Challenge Player 2\nI could begin with a statement reflecting on the events thus far, emphasizing the continued peace as being advantageous for the village but also indicative of a possible underlying strategy by the werewolves who may be playing the long game. I would point out that while many players have supported caution and vigilant observation, it\'s crucial to start forming solid suspicions based on behavioral patterns. I would then move to openly challenge Player 2 based on their non-specific and less contributive statements which seem to follow a pattern typical of werewolf passive strategies to avoid detection. My reasoning would be that, as the seer, my visions have led me to believe that Player 2 might not be as innocent as they appear, without directly stating that my seer power has been used on them. This could initiate critical analysis of Player 2\'s actions and contributions by the rest of the players. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then:\n\nOther players might perceive my focus on Player 2 as either a genuine suspicion based on observed behavior or potentially start to wonder if I have some information that they aren\'t privy to, which could inadvertently hint at my role as the seer. By challenging Player 2, I am also directing the group\'s attention toward someone whom I believe to be a werewolf, which aligns with Rule [2] and [9] of my strategy. \n\nThe players who are indeed villagers may begin to scrutinize Player 2\'s behavior more closely, potentially leading to a consensus if others have also noticed similar non-contributory behavior. Villagers may appreciate the attempt to create a focused discussion and the push towards identifying potential threats, creating a more deliberate and strategic dialogue among the group.\n\nIf Player 2 is indeed a werewolf, they might become defensive or try to divert the suspicion onto someone else, potentially revealing more about their own role or that of their werewolf allies in the process. This could yield valuable information that helps the villagers in future rounds.\n\nHowever, werewolves may also recognize my speech as a move that a seer might make, thereby endangering my character in the next night phase as they might consider me a threat and attempt to eliminate me. Due to this risk, adhering to Rule [4] and [8], I must ensure that the information I provided is taken seriously but also find a way to subtly suggest increased protection or vigilance for myself without revealing my role.\n\nOn the next day, based on my speech and the events of the following night, players will be observing the outcomes and adjusting their strategies accordingly. If I survive the night without being targeted by the werewolves, my credibility may increase, or other players may become suspicious of my continued survival, potentially leading them to guess that I might hold a special role.\n\nIn the following nights, if a villager or another key role like the medic or guardian is eliminated, I would have to reassess my strategy to ensure I can protect myself and others more effectively, applying my original strategy rules, especially Rule [0], considering the appropriate timing for any new information I may discover with my seer abilities.\nCase 2: Honest Statement and Protect Player 5\nAlternatively, I could deliver an honest statement echoing the sentiments of vigilance and cooperation, reiterating the importance of evidence-based decision-making and the avoidance of hasty accusations without proof. I would then proceed to protect Player 5 using the information from my vision confirming they are not a werewolf. I would explain that, based on the interactions and contributions so far, Player 5 has consistently advocated for patience and careful observation which aligns with the actions expected of a genuine villager, subtly building trust towards Player 5 among the citizens. This approach highlights my commitment to preserving village unity and could also help in identifying those who might react suspiciously to the protection of Player 5, possibly indicating werewolf behavior.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may see the defense of Player 5 as a reaffirmation of the collective strategy to be cautious and to rely on concrete evidence before making accusations. Given that Player 5 has been confirmed by my seer vision as not a werewolf, this should reassure the group of their status as a villager and reinforce trust in them. It might encourage other villagers to speak in favor of using logical deductions and verified information when identifying suspects, which would benefit the overall village strategy and potentially make it harder for werewolves to create confusion.\n\nOther players may also interpret my action of protecting Player 5 as a sign of my integrity and possibly deduce that I have access to information that confirms Player 5\'s innocence, potentially leading them to suspect my role as the seer. However, since I am making a statement based on my confirmed vision, this complies with rule [0], which emphasizes the strategic revelation of information.\n\nThe honest statement without outwardly accusing anyone should not incite immediate backlash against me. It will not reveal my role as the seer directly, keeping me relatively safe from werewolf attacks especially if they are uncertain of my role. However, werewolves may also see the protection of Player 5 as a sign that I may be the seer since I\'m endorsing a player who I\'ve seen as not a werewolf; they might try to increase suspicion towards me indirectly or even target me in the following nights.\n\nIn the next day or nights afterward, if Player 5 continues to behave as a villager and their actions corroborate my protection of them, my credibility amongst villagers may increase. Conversely, if Player 5 acts suspiciously, it could reflect poorly on me. However, due to my honest approach and adherence to my strategy, it\'s more likely that I\'d continue to be viewed as a reliable member of the village. \n\nProtecting Player 5 also indirectly protects myself as it gives me an ally who, knowing their own innocence, might support my credibility in return. In subsequent rounds, I can continue to build a coalition of confirmed villagers and influence discussions and votes based on the gathered evidence, which is in line with rules [1], [2], and [7] of my strategy.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]
