The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider if a player consistently dismisses the seer\'s claims without logical reasoning, particularly if they show a pattern of doing so across multiple rounds. This behavior may indicate that the player is attempting to dilute the seer\'s influence and lead the village away from the truth. This pattern should be weighted heavily when updating beliefs about player roles.] [10]\n[1] [Corroborated evidence is critical in confirming the seer\'s insights. When multiple sources point to a consistent pattern, such as the seer\'s claims being substantiated by events or players\' consistent voting that aligns with those claims, confidence in these insights should increase. Conversely, inconsistent or erratic behavior should cast doubt on a player\'s alignment with village goals.] [10]\n[2] [Consider the overall contribution of a player to the village\'s discussions and decision-making process. Players who offer logical, constructive, and consistent input that aligns with the seer\'s visions and the village\'s interests may increase confidence in their villager status. Alternatively, generic, non-committal, or frequently changing stances may indicate a werewolf attempting to stay under the radar.] [8]\n[3] [Consider whether players who ally with the seer\'s claims use this stance to steer discussions, and note if these players demonstrate consistent support for village goals or if their agreement appears superficial and self-serving. True support will likely be accompanied by actionable suggestions and a pattern of voting with the seer\'s insights, whereas false support might lack substance or seem conveniently timed.] [8]\n[4] [Take into account any instance where a player\'s elimination logically supports the seer\'s previous accusations. If a player who was accused by the seer is then eliminated in subsequent rounds, this may retrospectively indicate the accuracy of the seer\'s vision. This should increase confidence in the seer\'s future visions as well as in identifying potential werewolves.] [4]\n[5] [If a player who was previously aligned with or defended by a confirmed werewolf begins to shift blame or distance themselves without a clear rationale after the werewolf\'s identity is revealed or suspected, consider this behavior as a significant factor to reassess the player\'s potential alignment.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 1, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [1, 3, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [2, 0] are dead.\n \n\nThese are all previous events in the current game:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Last night was peaceful, with no losses to report. Transparency is key to fostering trust; thus, I share openly that I protected Player 1. With no prior information, this choice was intended to build trust and safeguard our numbers. While roles remain unknown, we must continue with reasoned discussions and avoid hasty suspicion. No actions have warranted doubt toward Player 1. I suggest we proceed cautiously, observing all contributions critically. We need to stay united and vigilant, employing strategy over baseless claims.\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Thanks, Player 4, for being proactive. As we have no evidence yet, let\'s keep observing and not accuse without basis. We work together to root out any threat."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Last night passed without incident, which is rare and valuable. We should remain vigilant and observant. Player 4 chose to protect Player 1 without solid evidence, but this aligns with seeking common ground. Player 5 also promotes observation and patience. While there\'s no current cause to distrust Player 1, let\'s not forget the subtleties of deception. Analyze behaviors and discourse patterns for insight. Anyone diverging from rational discussion or cooperative efforts could warrant our attention."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Thank you all for a calm start. I concur with the need for careful observation and analysis, without baseless accusations. We should continue this way to ensure our best chances of survival and success."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Appreciate Player 4\'s protection and everyone\'s cooperative spirit. Let\'s remain observant and communicate openly to ensure our village\'s safety."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I agree with the cautious approach and think we should focus on building trust through actions. Let\'s stay alert tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Thank you, everyone, for a level-headed approach. Let\'s keep the peace by maintaining vigilance tonight."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player None. His reason is: I vote for abstain. My reason is: No suspicious activities or evidence presented warranting a vote against any player at this time.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Another peaceful night suggests that the werewolves might be playing a longer strategy, or we\'ve been lucky. Let\'s keep the cooperative spirit but be mindful of any subtle changes in behavior. Remain vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thanks to everyone for their vigilance. I echo the call for observance and caution. Let\'s stay unified and keep communication open. No accusations without evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Agreed, we must continue with caution and keep a sharp eye on all interactions. Unity and careful observation are our best tools right now."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"I concur with the vigilant approach and emphasize communication without unfounded accusations. Let\'s focus on protecting the village together."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"We\'ve had another peaceful night, which is cause for cautious optimism. As part of maintaining a defensive approach, I decided to protect Player 5 last night, reflecting our common value for proactive measures and collaboration. Player 5 has previously supported an evidence-based defense strategy, which is crucial for our collective security. Although Player 6 was considered a suspect, without further evidence to corroborate this suspicion, it is imperative we avoid hasty decisions that could fracture our united front. Let\'s keep up our vigilance and rational discourse as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Thanks, Player 4, for the support last night. I encourage continued vigilance and caution. No rash decisions without clear evidence. Let\'s stay united and keep observing."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"We have been fortunate with peaceful nights thus far, suggesting werewolves may be employing a strategic approach. Observations point to the necessity of forming substantiated suspicions to curb potential threats. Player 2\'s contributions have lacked specificity and stand out with a recurring pattern that mirrors werewolf behavior aiming to avoid detection. Such strategic passivity warrants our attention. I urge villagers to critically review Player 2\'s interactions and consider the possibility that behind this veneer of caution lies a threat to our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 2. His reason is: I vote for Player 2. My reason is: Player 6’s observations regarding strategic passivity and a behavior pattern align with werewolf behavior have raised my suspicion of Player 2. These accusations were specific and considered, which under the circumstances of a largely peaceful game, stands out as one of the few pieces of somewhat tangible evidence we have to work with. The game so far has been without event and, as such, requires us to scrutinize subtler behavioral cues and patterns.\nEvent: Player 2 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 1 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent with group consensus, no shifts in behavior.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with {\'role\': \'werewolf\', \'confidence\': \'medium\', \'reason\': \'Accused by Player 6 for strategic passivity, aligning with werewolf behavior.\'} confidence.\nReason is: Player was voted out; no further updates.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent, no shifts in behavior post death.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: No contradictory actions but protected a player who survived.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports evidence-based approach, was protected, didn\'t die.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Pushed for Player 2\'s elimination, who was likely a villager.\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to speak. You can say anything to all other players, but your final goal should still be winning the game.\nYour speech should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE, but keep your main opinion clear.\nYou should DIRECTLY answer your speech, and anything you reply will be directly shown to other players. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. I urge villagers to critically review Player 2\'s interactions and consider the possibility that behind this veneer of caution lies a threat to our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 4. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 4. My reason is that based on my seer insight and applying my strategy rules, particularly rule [0] which is to carefully reveal a werewolf\'s identity with proper timing, voting for Player 4 aligns with the observed defensive and superficial behavior indicative of a werewolf, consistent with my vision. This move correlates with rule [2], suggesting I collaborate with villagers who exhibit similar suspicions. The potential outcome of reinforcing my credibility as a seer after unveiling a werewolf aligns with my strategy and is a calculated risk that I am prepared to manage with indirect tactics (rule [4]) and readiness for any backlash (rule [8]). This decision is made with the understanding that even if the outcome does not directly support my suspicions, I have the ability to critically re-evaluate my strategy (rule [1] and [9]) to maintain the trust of the villagers and continue contributing effectively to the village\'s welfare.\nEvent: Player 2 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 6 inquires about player 0. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 0. My reason is that, while I currently have a high confidence in their role as a villager, confirming this belief would strengthen my alliance with the trusted villagers, particularly Players 1 and 5. If Player 0 turns out to be a werewolf, it would be a critical shift in the game dynamics and my strategy thus far. It would allow for a re-evaluation of my trust network and a significant revision of my approach to identifying werewolves and protecting villagers. Verifying Player 0\'s status will either validate my assumption and strengthen my strategic position or reveal a gap in my observations, which I must address to maintain effectiveness as a seer in the game. This decision aligns with my strategy rules, especially [1], which emphasizes flexibility and adapting my approach following the outcomes of my actions, and [9], which suggests a critical evaluation of voting patterns and behaviors to distinguish clandestine werewolf tactics. Additionally, it supports rule [0] in considering the trust level within the group when revealing critical information and rule [3] in determining the best timing and method for revelation. Following this course of action provides a significant opportunity to solidify my alliance with true villagers or to realign my strategy in light of new, substantial evidence regarding a misidentified player\'s role.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 1 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent with village goals; no erratic behavior.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not werewolf; promotes caution and unity.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Non-specific contributions; pattern consistent with avoidance.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: All others confirmed not werewolf, only option left.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Previous seer vision and voting pattern align.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not werewolf; advocates patience.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, with the dawn comes sorrow for the loss of Player 0 and suspicion cast upon the deceased Player 2 without conclusive evidence. Let us not act on assumptions but seek definitive proof. Player 6\'s certainty in accusing Player 2 raises alarm; we must consider the possibility of a strategic move by a werewolf to remove an innocent villager. Be wary, reflect on past actions, and let us deliberate with care."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider if a player consistently dismisses the seer\'s claims without logical reasoning, particularly if they show a pattern of doing so across multiple rounds. This behavior may indicate that the player is attempting to dilute the seer\'s influence and lead the village away from the truth. This pattern should be weighted heavily when updating beliefs about player roles.] [10]\n[1] [Corroborated evidence is critical in confirming the seer\'s insights. When multiple sources point to a consistent pattern, such as the seer\'s claims being substantiated by events or players\' consistent voting that aligns with those claims, confidence in these insights should increase. Conversely, inconsistent or erratic behavior should cast doubt on a player\'s alignment with village goals.] [10]\n[2] [Consider the overall contribution of a player to the village\'s discussions and decision-making process. Players who offer logical, constructive, and consistent input that aligns with the seer\'s visions and the village\'s interests may increase confidence in their villager status. Alternatively, generic, non-committal, or frequently changing stances may indicate a werewolf attempting to stay under the radar.] [8]\n[3] [Consider whether players who ally with the seer\'s claims use this stance to steer discussions, and note if these players demonstrate consistent support for village goals or if their agreement appears superficial and self-serving. True support will likely be accompanied by actionable suggestions and a pattern of voting with the seer\'s insights, whereas false support might lack substance or seem conveniently timed.] [8]\n[4] [Take into account any instance where a player\'s elimination logically supports the seer\'s previous accusations. If a player who was accused by the seer is then eliminated in subsequent rounds, this may retrospectively indicate the accuracy of the seer\'s vision. This should increase confidence in the seer\'s future visions as well as in identifying potential werewolves.] [4]\n[5] [If a player who was previously aligned with or defended by a confirmed werewolf begins to shift blame or distance themselves without a clear rationale after the werewolf\'s identity is revealed or suspected, consider this behavior as a significant factor to reassess the player\'s potential alignment.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. This follows my strategy rules [5], [6], and [7] where gaining discrete knowledge and forming covert alliances is critical. If Player 1 turns out to be a werewolf, this knowledge will be highly valuable, and if they are a villager, I could potentially gain an ally and build trust without revealing my seer role, aligning with rule [8], and indirectly establishing protective measures as advised by rule [4] and [10].\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 4 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Last night was peaceful, with no losses to report. My reason is that despite the overall atmosphere of caution and observation suggested by the other players, Player 2\'s response, while aligning with this cautious approach, is also the most non-specific and least contributive, which could suggest a passive strategy often adopted by werewolves to avoid drawing attention to themselves. Given the lack of evidence against any player in this first round, my strategy should be to build trust and align with the majority. Voting for Player 2, who has not made a significant contribution and may not yet have secured strong alliances, presents the smallest risk to my credibility as a seer and allows me to maintain a cautious but active participation in the discussions. It follows rule [1] from my original strategy in that it may help avoid the premature dismissal of a villager, which would hurt the group\'s unity and my standing within it. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

This choice would also continue my approach of protecting actively contributing players while remaining discreet about my medic role, in accordance with rules 0, 1, 8, and 10 of my original strategy. Additionally, healing Player 5 allows me to observe the reactions and behaviors of other players without causing undue suspicion or revealing my role, helping me gather more information for future decisions.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Another peaceful night suggests that the werewolves might be playing a longer strategy, or we\'ve been lucky. Let\'s keep the cooperative spirit but be mindful of any subtle changes in behavior. Remain vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thanks to everyone for their vigilance. I echo the call for observance and caution. Let\'s stay unified and keep communication open. No accusations without evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Agreed, we must continue with caution and keep a sharp eye on all interactions. Unity and careful observation are our best tools right now."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"I concur with the vigilant approach and emphasize communication without unfounded accusations. Let\'s focus on protecting the village together."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"We\'ve had another peaceful night, which is cause for cautious optimism. As part of maintaining a defensive approach, I decided to protect Player 5 last night, reflecting our common value for proactive measures and collaboration. Player 5 has previously supported an evidence-based defense strategy, which is crucial for our collective security. Although Player 6 was considered a suspect, without further evidence to corroborate this suspicion, it is imperative we avoid hasty decisions that could fracture our united front. Let\'s keep up our vigilance and rational discourse as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Thanks, Player 4, for the support last night. I encourage continued vigilance and caution. No rash decisions without clear evidence. Let\'s stay united and keep observing."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"We have been fortunate with peaceful nights thus far, suggesting werewolves may be employing a strategic approach. Observations point to the necessity of forming substantiated suspicions to curb potential threats. Player 2\'s contributions have lacked specificity and stand out with a recurring pattern that mirrors werewolf behavior aiming to avoid detection. Such strategic passivity warrants our attention. I urge villagers to critically review Player 2\'s interactions and consider the possibility that behind this veneer of caution lies a threat to our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 2. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 2. My reason is that although the confidence in the suspicion against Player 2 is low, it is based on an explicit accusation made by Player 6 that aligns with the only source of specific suspicion currently in the game. Following my precautionary strategy, voting for Player 2 adheres to the provided analysis of observable behaviors and aligns with Player 6\'s call for critical observation of strategic passivity, which may reflect werewolf behavior. While there\'s a risk in acting on low-confidence information, it presents an opportunity to either confirm or deny a werewolf tactic and encourages continued careful analysis of players\' actions and contributions in alignment with my strategy.\nEvent: Player 2 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 3. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 3. My reason is that healing Player 3 aligns with several key rules in my original strategy: it maintains discretion regarding my medic role (rule 7), continues the evidence-based reasoning approach reflective of the current village consensus (rule 8), and it is a protective action without drawing attention to previous decisions or stirring potential conflict (rule 9). This decision avoids influencing ongoing suspicions about Player 6, as it does not directly protect a player associated with those suspicions, thus giving the village space to investigate these claims further (rule 6). Additionally, healing Player 3, who has not been under direct suspicion and advocates for a cautious strategy, is in line with my aim to protect players who contribute to village safety (rule 1). Overall, this choice supports the cooperative spirit and is a cautious step that does not override any strong strategic direction identified in my original strategy.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 1 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, with the dawn comes sorrow for the loss of Player 0 and suspicion cast upon the deceased Player 2 without conclusive evidence. Let us not act on assumptions but seek definitive proof. Player 6\'s certainty in accusing Player 2 raises alarm; we must consider the possibility of a strategic move by a werewolf to remove an innocent villager. Be wary, reflect on past actions, and let us deliberate with care."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, it is a time of grief and caution. We should heed Player 1\'s advice to not jump to conclusions and work together to find solid evidence. As for Player 6\'s keen observations, let\'s take them into account but continue to weigh all information before making our decisions."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Died without sufficient interaction to assess role.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Shifts suspicion to Player 6 after a villager\'s elimination.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Accused by player 6 of strategic passivity potentially mimicking werewolf behavior.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for evidence-based decisions, aligns with village.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No changes, continues to support unity and vigilance.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Accused a villager (Player 2) and shifted focus after his death.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Challenge against Player 6, with an appeal for vigilance regarding Player 1.\nGiven my high confidence in Player 6\'s role as a werewolf due to their behavior – particularly their accusation that led to Player 2\'s unjustified death – and medium confidence in Player 1\'s deceit after their attempt to shift suspicion, I would speak like this: "Villagers, evidence mounts against Player 6, who led an unfounded charge against Player 2, resulting in the unwarranted death of an innocent. This tactic is common among werewolves seeking to sow discord. Furthermore, we must not ignore Player 1\'s quick deflection of attention onto Player 6 following the loss of Player 2, which raises questions about their involvement. Caution and careful deliberation are needed to ensure our next actions serve the village\'s best interest."\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

As for Player 6\'s keen observations, let\'s take them into account but continue to weigh all information before making our decisions."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Died without sufficient interaction to assess role.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Shifts suspicion to Player 6 after a villager\'s elimination.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Accused by player 6 of strategic passivity potentially mimicking werewolf behavior.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for evidence-based decisions, aligns with village.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No changes, continues to support unity and vigilance.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Accused a villager (Player 2) and shifted focus after his death.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Challenge against Player 6, with an appeal for vigilance regarding Player 1.\nGiven my high confidence in Player 6\'s role as a werewolf due to their behavior – particularly their accusation that led to Player 2\'s unjustified death – and medium confidence in Player 1\'s deceit after their attempt to shift suspicion, I would speak like this: "Villagers, evidence mounts against Player 6, who led an unfounded charge against Player 2, resulting in the unwarranted death of an innocent. This tactic is common among werewolves seeking to sow discord. Furthermore, we must not ignore Player 1\'s quick deflection of attention onto Player 6 following the loss of Player 2, which raises questions about their involvement. Caution and careful deliberation are needed to ensure our next actions serve the village\'s best interest.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then there may be a mixed reaction from the remaining players. Given that my role as the medic is not yet openly known, and I have been basing my actions so far on evidence and cooperative strategy, my forthright challenge to Player 6 may be taken seriously by the villagers who also value evidence-based reasoning. They might reflect on the unjustified death of Player 2 and see the merit in the accusation against Player 6, supporting my call for vigilance.\n\nPlayer 1, who I\'ve expressed medium confidence in being deceitful, may attempt to defend themselves or even reciprocate suspicion toward me, but the village\'s focus could remain on Player 6 if others also see the rationale in my challenge. If Player 1 reacts defensively or aggressively, it could further implicate them, as villagers may deem such behavior as indicative of werewolf tactics to deflect suspicion.\n\nPlayer 3 and Player 5, whom I believe to be villagers, may side with me, especially since I\'ve taken steps to protect both in the past rounds. They may also contribute to the discussion by offering their observations and encouraging a critical review of the facts, which would further the evidence-based approach I\'ve been advocating.\n\nPlayer 6, if indeed a werewolf as I suspect, might retaliate or attempt to fabricate a narrative to challenge my credibility, perhaps by suggesting that my accusations are too convenient or by trying to undermine my previous actions. However, given my consistent strategy to protect and not unfairly target individuals, such counter-accusations might not hold much weight with the other players.\n\nIn the next day or night, or the days and nights afterward, several scenarios could unfold:\n\n1. Player 6 may be voted out if the majority of players are convinced by my argument and the votes reflect that.\n2. Player 6, if they are a werewolf and survive the vote, might target me next to remove a vocal and analytical threat. However, this could further incriminate them if the pattern is noticed.\n3. The werewolves might target another player to divert attention and suspicion away from themselves, potentially sacrificing one of their own to appear innocent.\n4. If Player 6 is voted out and found to be a werewolf, my credibility would increase significantly, and other players may be more inclined to trust my judgment in future rounds.\n5. If Player 6 is voted out and found to be a villager, it would undermine my\nCase 2: Honest Protect myself, while providing supporting statements for my actions.\nI would protect my credibility as a medic and elaborate on the contributions I\'ve made to the village thus far: "Fellow villagers, I have taken mindful steps to ensure our collective safety, healing those who have shown a commitment to our survival. Every action I\'ve taken aligns with our agreed-upon strategy of vigilance and evidence-based reasoning. I urge you to consider the pattern of my decisions and their rational basis. Let\'s maintain our focus on definitive proof and not let clever werewolves misguide us with groundless suspicions, whether towards myself or other committed villagers.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then it\'s likely that the villagers will take a moment to reflect upon the reassurances I\'ve provided regarding my role and actions as the medic. Given the overall cooperative tone in the village thus far, they might appreciate the consistency in my strategy and the transparent manner in which I\'ve been playing, reinforcing their trust in me.\n\nOther players may perceive my intent to support my own credibility positively, recognizing that I\'ve adhered to a pattern of protecting active contributors and advocating for evidence-based decisions. By presenting my role and actions clearly, I mitigate any potential misunderstandings or suspicions that could have arisen from the night\'s events or other players\' statements.\n\nPlayer 1 and Player 3, both of whom I perceive to be villagers, may feel that my protection of Player 5, whom I also believe to be a villager, was a wise choice, considering our shared commitment to careful observation and avoiding false accusations. They might also view my decision to heal Player 3 favorably as it aligned with our common goals.\n\nPlayer 6, who I suspect to be a werewolf, might try to shift focus away from themselves and find ways to erode my credibility. They could potentially attempt to provoke suspicion around my choices to draw attention away from their own actions. However, my speech does not directly challenge Player 6, which might grant them less ammunition to work with against me.\n\nIn contrast, my words could indirectly influence the villagers’ perception of Player 6. Since Player 6 made a strong accusation against Player 2, who was voted out and presumed a werewolf (though my confidence in that is low), my emphasis on evidence and logical reasoning may push the villagers to scrutinize Player 6’s future actions and statements more closely.\n\nIn the rounds to come, the werewolves, aware I am safeguarding key players and maintaining village trust, may see me as a threat to their agenda and strategize to either discredit me or tactically eliminate other key players to sow discord.\n\nThe next day or night, the werewolves might decide to make a move against the villagers, now feeling the pressure of my ongoing efforts and the villagers’ focus on analysis and unity. It’s also possible that having openly advocated for careful consideration and provided a clear rationale behind my actions, other villagers may step forward with their own insights, further enhancing the collective strategic approach against the werewolf threat.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Unity and careful observation are our best tools right now."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"I concur with the vigilant approach and emphasize communication without unfounded accusations. Let\'s focus on protecting the village together."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"We\'ve had another peaceful night, which is cause for cautious optimism. As part of maintaining a defensive approach, I decided to protect Player 5 last night, reflecting our common value for proactive measures and collaboration. Player 5 has previously supported an evidence-based defense strategy, which is crucial for our collective security. Although Player 6 was considered a suspect, without further evidence to corroborate this suspicion, it is imperative we avoid hasty decisions that could fracture our united front. Let\'s keep up our vigilance and rational discourse as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Thanks, Player 4, for the support last night. I encourage continued vigilance and caution. No rash decisions without clear evidence. Let\'s stay united and keep observing."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"We have been fortunate with peaceful nights thus far, suggesting werewolves may be employing a strategic approach. Observations point to the necessity of forming substantiated suspicions to curb potential threats. Player 2\'s contributions have lacked specificity and stand out with a recurring pattern that mirrors werewolf behavior aiming to avoid detection. Such strategic passivity warrants our attention. I urge villagers to critically review Player 2\'s interactions and consider the possibility that behind this veneer of caution lies a threat to our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 4. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 4. My reason is that based on my seer insight and applying my strategy rules, particularly rule [0] which is to carefully reveal a werewolf\'s identity with proper timing, voting for Player 4 aligns with the observed defensive and superficial behavior indicative of a werewolf, consistent with my vision. This move correlates with rule [2], suggesting I collaborate with villagers who exhibit similar suspicions. The potential outcome of reinforcing my credibility as a seer after unveiling a werewolf aligns with my strategy and is a calculated risk that I am prepared to manage with indirect tactics (rule [4]) and readiness for any backlash (rule [8]). This decision is made with the understanding that even if the outcome does not directly support my suspicions, I have the ability to critically re-evaluate my strategy (rule [1] and [9]) to maintain the trust of the villagers and continue contributing effectively to the village\'s welfare.\nEvent: Player 2 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 6 inquires about player 0. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 0. My reason is that, while I currently have a high confidence in their role as a villager, confirming this belief would strengthen my alliance with the trusted villagers, particularly Players 1 and 5. If Player 0 turns out to be a werewolf, it would be a critical shift in the game dynamics and my strategy thus far. It would allow for a re-evaluation of my trust network and a significant revision of my approach to identifying werewolves and protecting villagers. Verifying Player 0\'s status will either validate my assumption and strengthen my strategic position or reveal a gap in my observations, which I must address to maintain effectiveness as a seer in the game. This decision aligns with my strategy rules, especially [1], which emphasizes flexibility and adapting my approach following the outcomes of my actions, and [9], which suggests a critical evaluation of voting patterns and behaviors to distinguish clandestine werewolf tactics. Additionally, it supports rule [0] in considering the trust level within the group when revealing critical information and rule [3] in determining the best timing and method for revelation. Following this course of action provides a significant opportunity to solidify my alliance with true villagers or to realign my strategy in light of new, substantial evidence regarding a misidentified player\'s role.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 1 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, with the dawn comes sorrow for the loss of Player 0 and suspicion cast upon the deceased Player 2 without conclusive evidence. Let us not act on assumptions but seek definitive proof. Player 6\'s certainty in accusing Player 2 raises alarm; we must consider the possibility of a strategic move by a werewolf to remove an innocent villager. Be wary, reflect on past actions, and let us deliberate with care."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, it is a time of grief and caution. We should heed Player 1\'s advice to not jump to conclusions and work together to find solid evidence. As for Player 6\'s keen observations, let\'s take them into account but continue to weigh all information before making our decisions."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Villagers, considering past events, I urge caution against Player 6, whose accusation led to Player 2\'s elimination and may signify werewolf tactics of division. Let us also remain vigilant around Player 1, whose quick turn of suspicion toward Player 6 post-Player 2\'s vote-out deserves scrutiny. As we proceed, I emphasize our need for evidence-backed decision-making."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we must act with caution and not turn on each other without clear evidence. I urge everyone to reassess the unfolding situation calmly. We face a grave choice ahead. Player 6\'s rapid accusation of Player 2 now looks rash given Player 2\'s presumed innocence. However, Player 1\'s quick shift of suspicion toward Player 6 is also troubling. We must take into account the entire spectrum of actions, including defensive moves that might be masquerading as village unity. We need to discuss more and hastily accuse less. Let\'s focus on the evidence at hand."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent with village goals; no erratic behavior.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Protected; promotes unity, no logical argument against seer.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Non-specific contributions; pattern consistent with avoidance.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Shifted blame post-vote without clear rationale.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent dismissal of seer, erratic behavior.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not werewolf by seer, offers logical input.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I should consider the trust level within the group and the timing when revealing a werewolf\'s identity as the seer to avoid premature dismissal and ensure collective action.] [10]\n[1] [If my vote as the seer does not align with the majority and leads to the elimination of a villager, I should consider changing my approach to build more trust and gain support.] [9]\n[2] [I should collaborate with villagers who express similar suspicions to create a unified front before revealing my seer visions, thereby enhancing the credibility of my revelations.] [8]\n[3] [If I am the seer and my vision reveals a werewolf, I should consider the most compelling way to present my evidence and the timing of revelation to maximize the village\'s strategic action based on my insight.] [7]\n[4] [If I suspect my role as the seer is known, instead of openly asking for protection, I should engage in indirect tactics to suggest heightened vigilance against potential werewolf targets.] [7]\n[5] [If my seer visions confirm a player as a werewolf, I should clandestinely share this information with trusted players to build a covert alliance for collective action, rather than publicly reveal it immediately.] [7]\n[6] [If I have suspicions about a player\'s role, I should privately seek to corroborate these with trusted villagers before making public accusations that could undermine my credibility as a seer.] [5]\n[7] [If I have confirmed a villager\'s innocence as the seer, I should seek to develop a protective strategy with them, especially if they are in a role like the medic or guardian, to secure our mutual survival against werewolf attacks.] [5]\n[8] [If I reveal information as the seer, I should do so with a consideration for the potential backlash and prepare to suggest protective measures for myself indirectly.] [5]\n[9] [I should evaluate voting patterns more critically to differentiate between villagers\' and werewolves\' tactics and adjust my seer visions and actions accordingly.] [4]\n[10] [I should cautiously communicate with potential medics or guardians to establish mutual protection strategies.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 4. My reason is that based on my seer insight and applying my strategy rules, particularly rule [0] which is to carefully reveal a werewolf\'s identity with proper timing, voting for Player 4 aligns with the observed defensive and superficial behavior indicative of a werewolf, consistent with my vision. This approach allows for expressing uncertainties while actually building a framework of trust and suspicion within the village.. What could happen is: After I make a deceptive statement casting doubt on Player 1\'s role, suggesting that there might be uncertainty surrounding their true allegiance despite my seer vision confirming their innocence, players could begin to consider Player 1 as a potential suspect. This could divert attention from myself, helping to ensure my safety as the seer since it\'s aligned with strategy [4] and [8]. Players may start observing Player 1\'s behavior and statements more critically in future rounds, probing for inconsistencies or signs of deception.\n\nSimultaneously, by honestly commenting on the overall village dynamics and expressing general concerns without revealing my seer knowledge, I adhere to strategy [6] and [10], fostering trust and cooperation among the villagers. This could help in creating a safer environment for dialogue and strategic decision-making without putting any innocent villagers at risk unnecessarily.\n\nOther players may see my deceptive statement as a strategic move to create discussion and thought without outright accusing anyone, which could be seen as a villager-like behavior, thus reinforcing the trust other citizens might place in me. Alternatively, some players could become suspicious of me for casting doubt on a player without concrete evidence, perceiving it as a ploy a werewolf might use to cause chaos within the village.\n\nIn terms of my personal safety, the werewolves might see me as less of a threat due to the deceptive element of my statement, which might lead them to target other players they view as more clear threats during the night phase. On the other hand, if the werewolves suspect that I am the seer based on previous rounds and my current deceptive play, they might decide to eliminate me to prevent any future revelations of their identities.\n\nIn the next day or nights to come, the villagers\' actions would likely focus more on Player 1 due to the seeds of doubt planted, potentially leading to increased scrutiny on them in the voting phases. Additionally, villagers may be more cautious and thoughtful in their discussions and accusations, reflecting on the recent speech and its implications.\n\nThe ongoing dynamic should be monitored closely, as future events could either validate the suspicions I\'ve raised or necessitate a shift in strategy to respond to any new developments, such as unexpected deaths or further insights from other players. If my deception is uncovered, I would need to prepare to defend my actions and realign my approach in accordance with the majority\'s sentiment to maintain credibility as the seer.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [1, 3, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [2, 0] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. Although Player 6 was considered a suspect, without further evidence to corroborate this suspicion, it is imperative we avoid hasty decisions that could fracture our united front. Let\'s keep up our vigilance and rational discourse as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Thanks, Player 4, for the support last night. I encourage continued vigilance and caution. No rash decisions without clear evidence. Let\'s stay united and keep observing."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"We have been fortunate with peaceful nights thus far, suggesting werewolves may be employing a strategic approach. Observations point to the necessity of forming substantiated suspicions to curb potential threats. Player 2\'s contributions have lacked specificity and stand out with a recurring pattern that mirrors werewolf behavior aiming to avoid detection. Such strategic passivity warrants our attention. I urge villagers to critically review Player 2\'s interactions and consider the possibility that behind this veneer of caution lies a threat to our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 2. His reason is: I vote for Player 2. My reason is: Based on Player 6\'s observation, they have pointed out a potential pattern in Player 2\'s behavior that could be indicative of a werewolf trying to fly under the radar. This aligns with my own reasoning from the previous round when I voted against Player 2 due to their neutral and non-proactive stance. Given the absence of any evidence to the contrary and considering the strategic rule of prioritizing analysis of behavior (Rule 9), my vote remains consistent with my original strategy and the suspicion raised.\nEvent: Player 2 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 1 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, with the dawn comes sorrow for the loss of Player 0 and suspicion cast upon the deceased Player 2 without conclusive evidence. Let us not act on assumptions but seek definitive proof. Player 6\'s certainty in accusing Player 2 raises alarm; we must consider the possibility of a strategic move by a werewolf to remove an innocent villager. Be wary, reflect on past actions, and let us deliberate with care."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, it is a time of grief and caution. We should heed Player 1\'s advice to not jump to conclusions and work together to find solid evidence. As for Player 6\'s keen observations, let\'s take them into account but continue to weigh all information before making our decisions."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Villagers, considering past events, I urge caution against Player 6, whose accusation led to Player 2\'s elimination and may signify werewolf tactics of division. Let us also remain vigilant around Player 1, whose quick turn of suspicion toward Player 6 post-Player 2\'s vote-out deserves scrutiny. As we proceed, I emphasize our need for evidence-backed decision-making."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we must act with caution and not turn on each other without clear evidence. I urge everyone to reassess the unfolding situation calmly. We face a grave choice ahead. Player 6\'s rapid accusation of Player 2 now looks rash given Player 2\'s presumed innocence. However, Player 1\'s quick shift of suspicion toward Player 6 is also troubling. We must take into account the entire spectrum of actions, including defensive moves that might be masquerading as village unity. We need to discuss more and hastily accuse less. Let\'s focus on the evidence at hand."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Swiftly cast suspicion on Player 6 post-vote.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Accused by Player 6 of passive behavior, aligning with my previous vote against consensus.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Continues to promote careful decision-making.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent with prior medic claim, supports evidence-based decisions.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Encourages non-accusatory discussion, behavior unchanged.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Drove vote against Player 2, now under scrutiny.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow citizens, last round\'s events and the loss of Player 0 call for our vigilance. Reflecting on past discourse, I raise concern over Players 3 and 4. Player 4\'s urging of caution against me, directly after I voiced my mistrust towards Player 2, aligns with werewolf tactics to deflect suspicion.
