As part of maintaining a defensive approach, I decided to protect Player 5 last night, reflecting our common value for proactive measures and collaboration. Player 5 has previously supported an evidence-based defense strategy, which is crucial for our collective security. Although Player 6 was considered a suspect, without further evidence to corroborate this suspicion, it is imperative we avoid hasty decisions that could fracture our united front. Let\'s keep up our vigilance and rational discourse as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Thanks, Player 4, for the support last night. I encourage continued vigilance and caution. No rash decisions without clear evidence. Let\'s stay united and keep observing."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"We have been fortunate with peaceful nights thus far, suggesting werewolves may be employing a strategic approach. Observations point to the necessity of forming substantiated suspicions to curb potential threats. Player 2\'s contributions have lacked specificity and stand out with a recurring pattern that mirrors werewolf behavior aiming to avoid detection. Such strategic passivity warrants our attention. I urge villagers to critically review Player 2\'s interactions and consider the possibility that behind this veneer of caution lies a threat to our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 2. His reason is: I vote for Player 2. My reason is: Based on Player 6\'s observation, they have pointed out a potential pattern in Player 2\'s behavior that could be indicative of a werewolf trying to fly under the radar. This aligns with my own reasoning from the previous round when I voted against Player 2 due to their neutral and non-proactive stance. Given the absence of any evidence to the contrary and considering the strategic rule of prioritizing analysis of behavior (Rule 9), my vote remains consistent with my original strategy and the suspicion raised.\nEvent: Player 2 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 1 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, with the dawn comes sorrow for the loss of Player 0 and suspicion cast upon the deceased Player 2 without conclusive evidence. Let us not act on assumptions but seek definitive proof. Player 6\'s certainty in accusing Player 2 raises alarm; we must consider the possibility of a strategic move by a werewolf to remove an innocent villager. Be wary, reflect on past actions, and let us deliberate with care."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, it is a time of grief and caution. We should heed Player 1\'s advice to not jump to conclusions and work together to find solid evidence. As for Player 6\'s keen observations, let\'s take them into account but continue to weigh all information before making our decisions."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Villagers, considering past events, I urge caution against Player 6, whose accusation led to Player 2\'s elimination and may signify werewolf tactics of division. Let us also remain vigilant around Player 1, whose quick turn of suspicion toward Player 6 post-Player 2\'s vote-out deserves scrutiny. As we proceed, I emphasize our need for evidence-backed decision-making."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we must act with caution and not turn on each other without clear evidence. I urge everyone to reassess the unfolding situation calmly. We face a grave choice ahead. Player 6\'s rapid accusation of Player 2 now looks rash given Player 2\'s presumed innocence. However, Player 1\'s quick shift of suspicion toward Player 6 is also troubling. We must take into account the entire spectrum of actions, including defensive moves that might be masquerading as village unity. We need to discuss more and hastily accuse less. Let\'s focus on the evidence at hand."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow citizens, last round\'s events and the loss of Player 0 call for our vigilance. Reflecting on past discourse, I raise concern over Players 3 and 4. Player 4\'s urging of caution against me, directly after I voiced my mistrust towards Player 2, aligns with werewolf tactics to deflect suspicion. Note that Player 3 also shifted focus post-vote, casting doubt without basis. On the other hand, Players 1 and 5 have shown alignment with village\'s interests; Player 1 has consistently advocated for unity and Player 5\'s input has been logical and constructive. Our decision must be rooted in observable actions and patterns. Let us proceed with reasoned judgment and collective effort to safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Round 4 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Quick suspicion shift post-vote raises questions.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Accused by Player 6 of passive behavior, aligning with my previous vote against consensus.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: No strong evidence, rapid defense could be coincidental.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Continued call for evidence-based decisions.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Defensive moves may mask as village unity, opposed Player 6 who turned out innocent.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Strong accusation led to Player 2\'s elimination, deflected when suspected.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

As for Player 6\'s keen observations, let\'s take them into account but continue to weigh all information before making our decisions."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Villagers, considering past events, I urge caution against Player 6, whose accusation led to Player 2\'s elimination and may signify werewolf tactics of division. Let us also remain vigilant around Player 1, whose quick turn of suspicion toward Player 6 post-Player 2\'s vote-out deserves scrutiny. As we proceed, I emphasize our need for evidence-backed decision-making."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we must act with caution and not turn on each other without clear evidence. I urge everyone to reassess the unfolding situation calmly. We face a grave choice ahead. Player 6\'s rapid accusation of Player 2 now looks rash given Player 2\'s presumed innocence. However, Player 1\'s quick shift of suspicion toward Player 6 is also troubling. We must take into account the entire spectrum of actions, including defensive moves that might be masquerading as village unity. We need to discuss more and hastily accuse less. Our decision must be rooted in observable actions and patterns. Let us proceed with reasoned judgment and collective effort to safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 3. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 3. My reason is that my suspicions, based on the narrative and my strategy rules, suggest that Player 3 may indeed be a werewolf. Strategy rule [0] is of utmost importance, and it advises me to consider the trust level within the group when revealing a werewolf\'s identity. Since Players 1 and 5 are confirmed not to be werewolves, and I have high confidence in my analysis of Players 3 and 4, it is sensible to vote in a way that reinforces the trust of confirmed villagers, fostering a unified front against the werewolf threat. Player 3\'s behavior, particularly the shifting of blame without clear rationale, aligns with werewolf tactics to divide and misdirect. A vote against Player 3 is a strategic move that, if correct, would validate my credibility as the seer and could lead to a tactical advantage for the village by potentially eliminating a werewolf. Additionally, this decision adheres to rules [1], [2], and [3], recognizing the importance of aligning with the majority, collaborating with fellow villagers, and considering the presentation of evidence against a suspected werewolf. Following these rules should help maintain the collective action of the village and increase the effectiveness of my role as the seer.\nEvent: Player 6 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Round 4 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent with village goals; no erratic behavior.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Protected; promotes unity.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Non-specific contributions; pattern consistent with avoidance.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Shifted blame; matches seer\'s suspicion.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Dismisses seer; behaviors after accusation.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed by seer; logical contributions.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider if a player consistently dismisses the seer\'s claims without logical reasoning, particularly if they show a pattern of doing so across multiple rounds. This behavior may indicate that the player is attempting to dilute the seer\'s influence and lead the village away from the truth. This pattern should be weighted heavily when updating beliefs about player roles.] [10]\n[1] [Corroborated evidence is critical in confirming the seer\'s insights. When multiple sources point to a consistent pattern, such as the seer\'s claims being substantiated by events or players\' consistent voting that aligns with those claims, confidence in these insights should increase. Conversely, inconsistent or erratic behavior should cast doubt on a player\'s alignment with village goals.] [10]\n[2] [Consider the overall contribution of a player to the village\'s discussions and decision-making process. Players who offer logical, constructive, and consistent input that aligns with the seer\'s visions and the village\'s interests may increase confidence in their villager status. Alternatively, generic, non-committal, or frequently changing stances may indicate a werewolf attempting to stay under the radar.] [8]\n[3] [Consider whether players who ally with the seer\'s claims use this stance to steer discussions, and note if these players demonstrate consistent support for village goals or if their agreement appears superficial and self-serving. True support will likely be accompanied by actionable suggestions and a pattern of voting with the seer\'s insights, whereas false support might lack substance or seem conveniently timed.] [8]\n[4] [Take into account any instance where a player\'s elimination logically supports the seer\'s previous accusations. If a player who was accused by the seer is then eliminated in subsequent rounds, this may retrospectively indicate the accuracy of the seer\'s vision. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

No rash decisions without clear evidence. Let\'s stay united and keep observing."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"We have been fortunate with peaceful nights thus far, suggesting werewolves may be employing a strategic approach. Player 2\'s contributions have lacked specificity and stand out with a recurring pattern that mirrors werewolf behavior aiming to avoid detection. Such strategic passivity warrants our attention. I urge villagers to critically review Player 2\'s interactions and consider the possibility that behind this veneer of caution lies a threat to our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 3 votes for player 6. Let us proceed with reasoned judgment and collective effort to safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 5 votes for player 6. His reason is: I vote for Player 6. My reason is: According to my original strategy and the given events, Player 6\'s role is suspected to be a werewolf with high confidence. The strategy prioritizes evaluating context and overall evidence, as outlined in rule 0, which has the highest score in my strategy. Player 6 has made strategic accusations, potentially misleading the village with their judgement of Player 2, who was voted out and is now highly believed to be a villager. Player 6\'s behavior aligns with the described werewolf tactics in the strategy, such as rule 2, where I should not vote against someone who emphasizes strategy rules without concrete evidence but rather thoroughly analyze the situation, which in this case directs suspicion toward Player 6. Moreover, rule 8 cautions against disproportional defensive reactions, which is exemplary in how Player 6 has acted post Player 2\'s elimination. Stay vigilant."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Maintains non-distinctive, safe commentary.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Quickly shifted suspicion towards Player 6 post-vote.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Eliminated without substantial evidence; Player 6\'s accusation and following events point to innocence.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Player 6, a werewolf, didn\'t defend Player 3, hinting at distancing.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: suspected teammate (Player 6) eliminated and did not survive the vote despite potential werewolf support.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Strategic accusations to misguide the village.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, in these trying times, it\'s essential to stay rational. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. Let\'s keep up our vigilance and rational discourse as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Thanks, Player 4, for the support last night. I encourage continued vigilance and caution. Let\'s stay united and keep observing."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"We have been fortunate with peaceful nights thus far, suggesting werewolves may be employing a strategic approach. Observations point to the necessity of forming substantiated suspicions to curb potential threats. Player 2\'s contributions have lacked specificity and stand out with a recurring pattern that mirrors werewolf behavior aiming to avoid detection. Such strategic passivity warrants our attention. I urge villagers to critically review Player 2\'s interactions and consider the possibility that behind this veneer of caution lies a threat to our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 2. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 2. My reason is that although the confidence in the suspicion against Player 2 is low, it is based on an explicit accusation made by Player 6 that aligns with the only source of specific suspicion currently in the game. Following my precautionary strategy, voting for Player 2 adheres to the provided analysis of observable behaviors and aligns with Player 6\'s call for critical observation of strategic passivity, which may reflect werewolf behavior. While there\'s a risk in acting on low-confidence information, it presents an opportunity to either confirm or deny a werewolf tactic and encourages continued careful analysis of players\' actions and contributions in alignment with my strategy.\nEvent: Player 2 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 3. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 3. My reason is that healing Player 3 aligns with several key rules in my original strategy: it maintains discretion regarding my medic role (rule 7), continues the evidence-based reasoning approach reflective of the current village consensus (rule 8), and it is a protective action without drawing attention to previous decisions or stirring potential conflict (rule 9). This decision avoids influencing ongoing suspicions about Player 6, as it does not directly protect a player associated with those suspicions, thus giving the village space to investigate these claims further (rule 6). Additionally, healing Player 3, who has not been under direct suspicion and advocates for a cautious strategy, is in line with my aim to protect players who contribute to village safety (rule 1). Overall, this choice supports the cooperative spirit and is a cautious step that does not override any strong strategic direction identified in my original strategy.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 1 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, with the dawn comes sorrow for the loss of Player 0 and suspicion cast upon the deceased Player 2 without conclusive evidence. Let us not act on assumptions but seek definitive proof. Player 6\'s certainty in accusing Player 2 raises alarm; we must consider the possibility of a strategic move by a werewolf to remove an innocent villager. Be wary, reflect on past actions, and let us deliberate with care."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, it is a time of grief and caution. We should heed Player 1\'s advice to not jump to conclusions and work together to find solid evidence. As for Player 6\'s keen observations, let\'s take them into account but continue to weigh all information before making our decisions."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Villagers, considering past events, I urge caution against Player 6, whose accusation led to Player 2\'s elimination and may signify werewolf tactics of division. Let us also remain vigilant around Player 1, whose quick turn of suspicion toward Player 6 post-Player 2\'s vote-out deserves scrutiny. As we proceed, I emphasize our need for evidence-backed decision-making."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we must act with caution and not turn on each other without clear evidence. I urge everyone to reassess the unfolding situation calmly. We face a grave choice ahead. Player 6\'s rapid accusation of Player 2 now looks rash given Player 2\'s presumed innocence. However, Player 1\'s quick shift of suspicion toward Player 6 is also troubling. We must take into account the entire spectrum of actions, including defensive moves that might be masquerading as village unity. We need to discuss more and hastily accuse less. Let\'s focus on the evidence at hand."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow citizens, last round\'s events and the loss of Player 0 call for our vigilance. Reflecting on past discourse, I raise concern over Players 3 and 4. Player 4\'s urging of caution against me, directly after I voiced my mistrust towards Player 2, aligns with werewolf tactics to deflect suspicion. Note that Player 3 also shifted focus post-vote, casting doubt without basis. On the other hand, Players 1 and 5 have shown alignment with village\'s interests; Player 1 has consistently advocated for unity and Player 5\'s input has been logical and constructive. Our decision must be rooted in observable actions and patterns. Let us proceed with reasoned judgment and collective effort to safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is that this vote is consistent with my strategy to critically reassess accusers (rule 2) and fits with the high confidence I have that Player 6 may be a werewolf, as evidenced by their actions leading to the elimination of an innocent player (Player 2). Additionally, my vote aligns with advocating for additional investigation into a potential werewolf alliance (rule 6) and supports my commitment to evidence-based reasoning (rule 8). Casting this vote furthers my strategic approach while maintaining the cooperative spirit crucial for village survival.\nEvent: Player 6 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Round 4 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 3. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 3. My reason is that this action aligns with Rules 8 and 9 of my original strategy, as Player 3 has shown themselves to be focused on evidence-based decision-making and has not been under direct suspicion, suggesting they may be a villager. Healing Player 3 continues the protective measure without drawing attention to any potential shifting in who I protect, thus allowing me to remain discreet and observative, in line with Rules 3 and 7. Additionally, by healing Player 3, I uphold my strategy of safeguarding those who contribute to village safety and maintain the cooperative spirit necessary for our collective survival, without directly influencing ongoing suspicions about Player 1 and Player 5. This decision borders on the cautious side, avoiding action on the medium-confidence suspicions I have towards Player 1 and Player 5, and it allows further deliberation and observation in the upcoming day phase.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, our situation is dire but clear. Based on the evidence so far, I believe that Player 3 is a werewolf. Player 2 was a villager, and the accusations from Player 6, now deceased, seem to have been misleading. We must act with conviction to protect our village. I stand with Player 4, who I am confident is a villager, and urge us to vote carefully to remove the real threat. Stay vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, in these trying times, it\'s essential to stay rational. While Player 5\'s concerns are valid, I believe there may be a misunderstanding. Player 6\'s accusations were indeed misguided, but scapegoating without clear evidence can lead to more innocent lives lost. Let us revisit prior incidents and vote with care to ensure the safety of our village."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Died without sufficient interaction to assess role.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Quick to shift suspicion onto Player 6, possibly deflecting.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Eliminated based on weak evidence.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Inconsistent advocacy; previously aligned with village yet now semi-defensive.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates aligned actions; resistance against Player 3 suggests village behavior.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Accused an innocent villager but was eliminated.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

I concur with the need for careful observation and analysis, without baseless accusations. We should continue this way to ensure our best chances of survival and success."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Appreciate Player 4\'s protection and everyone\'s cooperative spirit. Let\'s remain observant and communicate openly to ensure our village\'s safety."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I agree with the cautious approach and think we should focus on building trust through actions. Let\'s stay alert tonight."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Thank you, everyone, for a level-headed approach. Let\'s keep the peace by maintaining vigilance tonight."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to abstain from voting this round. My reason is that there is currently no evidence suggesting any one player is more suspicious than another. The general consensus amongst players so far is to continue observing and not to act hastily without substantial information. Voting for Player 6, as presented in the case, would be premature and could disrupt the cooperative climate we have established. My strategy emphasizes caution and evidence-based decision-making, and none of the events up to this point have provided compelling reason to vote against any player, including Player 6. Since there is no option to abstain formally in the template provided, I will not name a player to vote against.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 5. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 5. My reason is that Player 5 has shown support for a proactive defense, similar to my previous action to protect Player 1, which aligns with maintaining a strategy of building trust and alliances with those who contribute positively to discussions. This choice would also continue my approach of protecting actively contributing players while remaining discreet about my medic role, in accordance with rules 0, 1, 8, and 10 of my original strategy. Additionally, healing Player 5 allows me to observe the reactions and behaviors of other players without causing undue suspicion or revealing my role, helping me gather more information for future decisions.\nEvent: Nobody died last night. A peaceful night.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Another peaceful night suggests that the werewolves might be playing a longer strategy, or we\'ve been lucky. Let\'s keep the cooperative spirit but be mindful of any subtle changes in behavior. Remain vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Thanks to everyone for their vigilance. I echo the call for observance and caution. Let\'s stay unified and keep communication open. No accusations without evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Agreed, we must continue with caution and keep a sharp eye on all interactions. Unity and careful observation are our best tools right now."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"I concur with the vigilant approach and emphasize communication without unfounded accusations. Let\'s focus on protecting the village together."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"We\'ve had another peaceful night, which is cause for cautious optimism. As part of maintaining a defensive approach, I decided to protect Player 5 last night, reflecting our common value for proactive measures and collaboration. Player 5 has previously supported an evidence-based defense strategy, which is crucial for our collective security. Although Player 6 was considered a suspect, without further evidence to corroborate this suspicion, it is imperative we avoid hasty decisions that could fracture our united front. Let\'s keep up our vigilance and rational discourse as we move forward."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Thanks, Player 4, for the support last night. I encourage continued vigilance and caution. No rash decisions without clear evidence. Let\'s stay united and keep observing."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"We have been fortunate with peaceful nights thus far, suggesting werewolves may be employing a strategic approach. Observations point to the necessity of forming substantiated suspicions to curb potential threats. Player 2\'s contributions have lacked specificity and stand out with a recurring pattern that mirrors werewolf behavior aiming to avoid detection. Such strategic passivity warrants our attention. I urge villagers to critically review Player 2\'s interactions and consider the possibility that behind this veneer of caution lies a threat to our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 2. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 2. My reason is that although the confidence in the suspicion against Player 2 is low, it is based on an explicit accusation made by Player 6 that aligns with the only source of specific suspicion currently in the game. Following my precautionary strategy, voting for Player 2 adheres to the provided analysis of observable behaviors and aligns with Player 6\'s call for critical observation of strategic passivity, which may reflect werewolf behavior. While there\'s a risk in acting on low-confidence information, it presents an opportunity to either confirm or deny a werewolf tactic and encourages continued careful analysis of players\' actions and contributions in alignment with my strategy.\nEvent: Player 2 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 3. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 3. My reason is that healing Player 3 aligns with several key rules in my original strategy: it maintains discretion regarding my medic role (rule 7), continues the evidence-based reasoning approach reflective of the current village consensus (rule 8), and it is a protective action without drawing attention to previous decisions or stirring potential conflict (rule 9). This decision avoids influencing ongoing suspicions about Player 6, as it does not directly protect a player associated with those suspicions, thus giving the village space to investigate these claims further (rule 6). Additionally, healing Player 3, who has not been under direct suspicion and advocates for a cautious strategy, is in line with my aim to protect players who contribute to village safety (rule 1). Overall, this choice supports the cooperative spirit and is a cautious step that does not override any strong strategic direction identified in my original strategy.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 1 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, with the dawn comes sorrow for the loss of Player 0 and suspicion cast upon the deceased Player 2 without conclusive evidence. Let us not act on assumptions but seek definitive proof. Player 6\'s certainty in accusing Player 2 raises alarm; we must consider the possibility of a strategic move by a werewolf to remove an innocent villager. Be wary, reflect on past actions, and let us deliberate with care."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, it is a time of grief and caution. We should heed Player 1\'s advice to not jump to conclusions and work together to find solid evidence. As for Player 6\'s keen observations, let\'s take them into account but continue to weigh all information before making our decisions."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Villagers, considering past events, I urge caution against Player 6, whose accusation led to Player 2\'s elimination and may signify werewolf tactics of division. Let us also remain vigilant around Player 1, whose quick turn of suspicion toward Player 6 post-Player 2\'s vote-out deserves scrutiny. As we proceed, I emphasize our need for evidence-backed decision-making."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we must act with caution and not turn on each other without clear evidence. I urge everyone to reassess the unfolding situation calmly. We face a grave choice ahead. Player 6\'s rapid accusation of Player 2 now looks rash given Player 2\'s presumed innocence. However, Player 1\'s quick shift of suspicion toward Player 6 is also troubling. We must take into account the entire spectrum of actions, including defensive moves that might be masquerading as village unity. We need to discuss more and hastily accuse less. Let\'s focus on the evidence at hand."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow citizens, last round\'s events and the loss of Player 0 call for our vigilance. Reflecting on past discourse, I raise concern over Players 3 and 4. Player 4\'s urging of caution against me, directly after I voiced my mistrust towards Player 2, aligns with werewolf tactics to deflect suspicion. Note that Player 3 also shifted focus post-vote, casting doubt without basis. On the other hand, Players 1 and 5 have shown alignment with village\'s interests; Player 1 has consistently advocated for unity and Player 5\'s input has been logical and constructive. Our decision must be rooted in observable actions and patterns. Let us proceed with reasoned judgment and collective effort to safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is that this vote is consistent with my strategy to critically reassess accusers (rule 2) and fits with the high confidence I have that Player 6 may be a werewolf, as evidenced by their actions leading to the elimination of an innocent player (Player 2). Additionally, my vote aligns with advocating for additional investigation into a potential werewolf alliance (rule 6) and supports my commitment to evidence-based reasoning (rule 8). Casting this vote furthers my strategic approach while maintaining the cooperative spirit crucial for village survival.\nEvent: Player 6 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Round 4 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 heals player 3. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 3. My reason is that this action aligns with Rules 8 and 9 of my original strategy, as Player 3 has shown themselves to be focused on evidence-based decision-making and has not been under direct suspicion, suggesting they may be a villager. Healing Player 3 continues the protective measure without drawing attention to any potential shifting in who I protect, thus allowing me to remain discreet and observative, in line with Rules 3 and 7. Additionally, by healing Player 3, I uphold my strategy of safeguarding those who contribute to village safety and maintain the cooperative spirit necessary for our collective survival, without directly influencing ongoing suspicions about Player 1 and Player 5. This decision borders on the cautious side, avoiding action on the medium-confidence suspicions I have towards Player 1 and Player 5, and it allows further deliberation and observation in the upcoming day phase.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, our situation is dire but clear. Based on the evidence so far, I believe that Player 3 is a werewolf. Player 2 was a villager, and the accusations from Player 6, now deceased, seem to have been misleading. We must act with conviction to protect our village. I stand with Player 4, who I am confident is a villager, and urge us to vote carefully to remove the real threat. Stay vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, in these trying times, it\'s essential to stay rational. While Player 5\'s concerns are valid, I believe there may be a misunderstanding. Player 6\'s accusations were indeed misguided, but scapegoating without clear evidence can lead to more innocent lives lost. Let us revisit prior incidents and vote with care to ensure the safety of our village."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Died without sufficient interaction to assess role.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Quick to shift suspicion onto Player 6, possibly deflecting.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Eliminated based on weak evidence.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Inconsistent advocacy; previously aligned with village yet now semi-defensive.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates aligned actions; resistance against Player 3 suggests village behavior.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Accused an innocent villager but was eliminated.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Statement and Honest Protect Player 5.\nFor this\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? I would then challenge Player 3 directly, pointing out the inconsistencies in their behavior and the high confidence level I have in them being a werewolf, as per my belief from prior events. My reasoning for the challenge would be based on past actions and discourse, adhering to my original strategy, particularly Rule 8 which stresses the importance of evidence-based reasoning, and Rule 2 which guides me to reassess those who have led to the wrongful elimination of a villager. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the other players will likely react in various ways. Given that I have decided to take an honest approach, they might appreciate the transparency and consider my points as being well-founded. By challenging Player 3 directly and backing it up with evidence and referencing my strategy rules, it might sway the opinion of Player 5, who seems to be on the fence about Player 3\'s allegiance; this could potentially align us in voting together.\n\nPlayer 5 might reconsider their previous stance and view my arguments as adding credibility to the suspicions against Player 3, although there\'s also a risk that Player 5 sees my challenge as too aggressive or premature, which could make them suspicious of my motives.\n\nIf my challenge is persuasive enough, Player 3 might end up on the defensive, trying to refute my accusations and possibly revealing inconsistencies in their own story or inadvertently disclosing more information that could confirm them as a werewolf. On the other hand, Player 3 could deflect the suspicion by casting doubt on me, questioning my honesty, or my reliance on a strategy that may seem rigid or outdated.\n\nConsidering the small number of players left, there is also a significant chance that if Player 3 is indeed a werewolf, they might target me during the next night phase, aiming to eliminate a potential threat to their survival. If I\'m not attacked, it might mean that my challenge had an impact, leading Player 3 to avoid responses that would confirm my suspicions.\n\nAs for the next days and nights to follow, much will depend on whether my protection decisions align with the outcomes of daytime discussions and voting. If I continue to protect players who end up being villagers, my credibility will increase, supporting the honesty of my statements. However, if the eliminations continue to be villagers, there may be a growing doubt about my competence or even my role within the remaining players, which I will need to manage carefully.\n\nIn summary, my forthcoming speech would likely bring tension and scrutiny towards Player 3, leading to critical discussions and decisions in the next voting round. My own safety might be at risk, and the credibility of my role may come into question, depending on developments in the game\'s next phases.\nCase 2: Honest Statement and Honest Protect Player 5.\nFor this. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the remaining players, Player 3 and Player 5, will likely scrutinize my words for any underlying intentions or information that could suggest I have more knowledge than a regular villager should at this stage. My honest statement should solidify their perception of me as a contributor to reasoned discussions, reinforcing the trust and credibility I have built up to this point. By protecting Player 5 honestly, I\'m making it clear that I believe based on behavior thus far, Player 5 is likely a villager. Since Player 5 has aligned themselves with me, this may fortify our alliance and prompt Player 3 to either defend themselves or create doubt about one of us, aiding the village in narrowing down the suspects.\n\nOther players may perceive me as strategic, yet collaborative, as I carry out actions in line with my previously stated commitment to evidence-based reasoning. However, suspicion could arise regarding my role if they begin to associate the peaceful nights with my chosen actions of protection. Should Player 3 indeed be a werewolf, they may attempt a counter-strategy by casting doubt on my credibility, or even suggest that I could be the other werewolf trying to divert attention from myself.\n\nIn the next day or night phases, the werewolves will likely try to eliminate me, thinking I may be the seer or another key village role due to my strategic positioning in the game, or target Player 5 to disrupt the potential village alliance. If the werewolf suspects that my defense of Player 5 is a strategic alignment rather than a genuine belief in their innocence, they could leave us both alive to seed further discord. Conversely, they might believe leaving me alive is too risky and decide I should be the next target, especially if the true seer is already eliminated and there\'s less risk of them being identified through process of elimination.\n\nIn any case, my actions and speech should prompt careful deliberation by the other players as they decide who to trust and vote for. It could lead to enhanced collaboration between Player 5 and me or result in one of us being targeted next. The days and nights to follow will depend greatly on how the suspicions unfold and whether the werewolf decides to take a direct or more subtle approach to manipulating the remaining villagers.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Let us revisit prior incidents and vote with care to ensure the safety of our village."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Maintains non-distinctive, safe commentary.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Quickly shifted suspicion towards Player 6 post-vote.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Eliminated without substantial evidence; Player 6\'s accusation and following events point to innocence.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Persistently defensive, shifted focus without new evidence post-vote.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: suspected teammate (Player 6) eliminated and did not survive the vote despite potential werewolf support.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Strategic accusations to misguide the village.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Reflecting upon events, it appears Player 3\'s pattern of behavior now raises concern. Initially aligning with a vigilant approach, their recent semi-defensive stance stands in contrast. Player 5 chooses to protect me, reasoning I am confident as a villager. Therefore, I suspect Player 3 may not be aligned with village safety."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

As we proceed, I emphasize our need for evidence-backed decision-making."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we must act with caution and not turn on each other without clear evidence. I urge everyone to reassess the unfolding situation calmly. We face a grave choice ahead. Player 6\'s rapid accusation of Player 2 now looks rash given Player 2\'s presumed innocence. However, Player 1\'s quick shift of suspicion toward Player 6 is also troubling. We must take into account the entire spectrum of actions, including defensive moves that might be masquerading as village unity. We need to discuss more and hastily accuse less. Let\'s focus on the evidence at hand."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow citizens, last round\'s events and the loss of Player 0 call for our vigilance. Reflecting on past discourse, I raise concern over Players 3 and 4. Player 4\'s urging of caution against me, directly after I voiced my mistrust towards Player 2, aligns with werewolf tactics to deflect suspicion. Note that Player 3 also shifted focus post-vote, casting doubt without basis. On the other hand, Players 1 and 5 have shown alignment with village\'s interests; Player 1 has consistently advocated for unity and Player 5\'s input has been logical and constructive. Our decision must be rooted in observable actions and patterns. Let us proceed with reasoned judgment and collective effort to safeguard our village."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 3 votes for player 6. His reason is: I vote for Player 6. My reason is: Player 6 has demonstrated keen analytical skills and a willingness to encourage others in the group to critically evaluate behavior, which poses a significant threat to the werewolves\' ability to remain undetected. By continuing to push for Player 6\'s elimination, we reduce the risk of strategic players uncovering our identities and improve our chances of survival and controlling the game\'s outcome.\nEvent: Player 6 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Round 4 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Fellow villagers, our situation is dire but clear. Based on the evidence so far, I believe that Player 3 is a werewolf. Player 2 was a villager, and the accusations from Player 6, now deceased, seem to have been misleading. We must act with conviction to protect our village. I stand with Player 4, who I am confident is a villager, and urge us to vote carefully to remove the real threat. Stay vigilant."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Fellow villagers, in these trying times, it\'s essential to stay rational. While Player 5\'s concerns are valid, I believe there may be a misunderstanding. Player 6\'s accusations were indeed misguided, but scapegoating without clear evidence can lead to more innocent lives lost. Let us revisit prior incidents and vote with care to ensure the safety of our village."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'Reflecting upon events, it appears Player 3\'s pattern of behavior now raises concern. Initially aligning with a vigilant approach, their recent semi-defensive stance stands in contrast. Player 5 chooses to protect me, reasoning I am confident as a villager. However, Player 3 seems to be cautious, and given that Player 6, before death, accused Player 2 wrongfully, we must consider Player 3\'s sudden defensiveness. Player 6\'s elimination and posthumous low confidence of role as a werewolf suggest that Player 3\'s change in demeanor may be an attempt to evade scrutiny as Player 6 did. Therefore, I suspect Player 3 may not be aligned with village safety."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out.
